reviews.author: whalewhalewhale
reviews.comment_content:
Content is similar to HKDSE if you learn M2, but I think M1 students can manage, since they already have the main skills and concepts for differentiation and integration, which is the biggest coverage of the course.
- Continuity
- Differentiation
- Integration
- Mean Value Theorem
- Intermediate Value Theorem
- Absolute Function
- Limit
- L'Hopital Rule
- Linear Approximation + Newton's Method
- Fundamental Theorem of Calculus
reviews.comment_teaching: Not very good, to be honest. The professor has a very quick pace when teaching, sometimes it's hard to catch up, especially for those who did not take M2 or who did not learn the concept before. The professor also expects you to know everything, therefore may skip some parts, and does not thoroughly explain the concepts.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading is absolute. Class attendance and participation is not counted in your grade.
>85 is A range
>70 is B range
>50 is C range

The marking for long questions is quite generous. However, the MCs in exams have a heavy grading, since they count for 4 marks. So be careful.
reviews.comment_workload: There is quite a lot of WebWork assignments, but I would say the workload is not that heavy since the deadlines are far apart from each other. Additionally, you have unlimited tries on the questions, so you can easily get full marks for all assignments.

reviews.author: william_chk
reviews.comment_content:
Mostly M2 stuff together with a few theorems related to derivatives, e.g. L'Hopital's Rule. mean value theorem, etc

Week 1 Review of the concepts of functions and graphs.  (1.2-1.3; Appendix A.)
Week 2 Elementary functions.  (1.5-1.6; Appendix D.)
Week 3 Tangent and velocity; the limit of  a function and limit laws.  (2.1-2.3.)
Week 4 Continuity; limit at infinity; limit definition of derivative and rates of change.  (2.5-2.7.)
Week 5 Derivatives of basic functions; differentiation rules.  (2.8, 3.1-3.3.)
Week 6 Chain rule and implicit differentiation.  (2.8, 3.1-3.3.)
Week 7 Rates and related rates.  (3.7-3.9.)
Week 8 Linear approximation and differentials; Newton's method; Maximum and minimum values.  (3.10, 4.8, 4.1.)
Week 9 Mean Value Theorem; derivatives and the shape of a graph; L'Hopital's Rule.  (4.2-4.4.)
Week 10 Curve sketching; optimization problems.  (4.5-4.7.)
Week 11 Antiderivatives; areas and distance travelled.  (4.9, 5.1.)
Week 12 Definite integrals; Fundamental Theorem of Calculus.  (5.2-5.3.)
Week 13 Net change; substitution rule.  (5.4-5.5.)
reviews.comment_teaching:
Mainly writes on whiteboard in class, in most situation jotting down notes is needed. Teaching is also supplemented with learning outcomes & examples that will be posted on course website periodically.

Professor Lam clearly prepared thoroughly for class and could teach without drawing any reference to his notes throughout the whole lecture.
reviews.comment_grading:
quite good
The grading reflects how much you work on this course
reviews.comment_workload:
Not too high, webwork is the only required thing, around 10 questions, once per week.
Lectures and tutorials are optional. No attendance taken.
And for the webwork, you may try as many times as you like, as long as you get the correct answer at last, full credit is given.

reviews.author: Saba
reviews.comment_content:
Calculus. Half DSE-M2 stuff, half new things. Good luck if you are M1.
Here's a list(not complete) of non-M2 stuffs in this course:
Continuity, Differentiability, Intermediate Value Theorem, Mean Value Theorem, 'one-to-one' function, Solving problems with absolute functions, Sandwich(Squeeze) Theorem, Linear Approximation, Newton's Method, Critical Point, Rolle's Theorem, L'Hopital Rule, Reimann Sum, Fundamental Theorem of Calculus(A little more things than DSE M2)
reviews.comment_teaching:
Dr. Lam's English is clear, and he is willing to answer student's questions. However, his writes on the whiteboard in a less organised way, so it's not easy to follow. The teaching pace is slow, and he put too much time on explaining the fundamental knowledge that both M1 and M2 and even DSE Maths core should have covered, especially functions... He should have put more efforts on new topics such as L'Hopital Rule and more...

Mr. Kong's tutorial is better, at least he can demonstrate the examples clearly and remind us some important steps/tips in solving problems.

I think attending tutorial is more important than attending lecture. I skip most lectures that teaches M2 stuff.
reviews.comment_grading:
GRADING

Semi-absolute grading. Much fairer than previous semesters.
15% WebWork 35% Mid-term 50% Final
Total score
85-100%-->A range
70-85%-->B range
50-70%-->C range
40-50%-->D
0-40%-->Fail
Me:
WebWork Full mark
Mid-term 90/100 (Mean: 73.43 SD:15.77)
Final 65/100 (Mean: 63.46 SD:15.37)
Total 79/100 (Mean: 71.89 SD:12.94) -->B
You can see that getting a mean will give you B-, much fairer than the past.
reviews.comment_workload:
Homework: Basically 1 WebWork(Online homework) per week, each consists of 10-18 questions. Apart from the first one you will need 2-4 hours to finish one, not very heavy workload. You can attempt questions infinitely many times , so try your best to get full marks in them!
No attendance required for any lecture and tutorials
Exam: Do your best in the relatively simple mid-term to secure a better grade earlier. All contents will appear in final exam, so don't forget to practice on evaluating limits for the final. I focused too much on integration and didn't do a single question of limits before the final, so I lose at least 9 marks on some relatively simple limit MCs, sigh~~

reviews.author: yanjai
reviews.title: Chill
reviews.comment_content:
1. Number and intervals, inequalities and absolutes, functions and graphs, composite functions, exponential functions.

2.Trigonometric functions, inverse functions, logarithmic functions, inverse trigonometric functions.

3.Tangent and velocity, the limit of a function, limit laws.

4.Continuity, limits at infinity and horizontal asymptotes, derivatives and rates of change.

5.Basic derivatives, product and quotient rules, derivatives of trigonometric functions.

6.Chain rule, implicit differentiation, derivatives of inverse trigonometric functions and logarithmic functions.

7.Rates of change problems, related rates.

8.Linear approximations and differentials, maximum and minimum values.

9.Mean Value Theorem, derivatives and graphs, L’Hôpital’s rule.

10.Curve sketching, optimization problems, Newton’s Method.

11.Antiderivatives, areas and distances.

12.Definite integrals, the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus.

13.Applications of integrals, the substitution rule.
reviews.comment_teaching: basically repeats slides so study yourself. This a good opportunity to equip yourself with the ability to self-learning.
reviews.comment_grading:
Absolute grading, F < 40% < D < 50% < C's < 70% < B's < 85% < A's

It's like a more competitive version of DSE, you train more you score more. So dun be surprised to get a low mark. Derivations of theorems are more or less useless if you are not a L1 student so just skip right into drilling lol.
reviews.comment_workload: It depends. If you know the way to drill those papers and also have a not-bad math sense (like at least a 5 in m2 lol), and also start revision only like a week ahead of the exam, you are secured to get a B something. A range surely requires a constant effort in knowing the concepts thoroughly and drilling the papers regularly.

reviews.title: Math madness
reviews.comment_content:

reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor Ku is passionate about the subject matter, which shines through in his teaching style. However, his monotone delivery can make the class feel less dynamic. Also, he looks at the ceiling while teaching which is hilarious.
Nonetheless, I would not recommend attending the lectures, as the material covered is fairly easy. Instead, I suggest attending Phyllis Liang's tutorial sessions. Her tutorial notes are exceptional, and by reviewing them before attempting past papers, you'll find significant assistance in your preparation.
reviews.comment_grading:
The difficulty ranking for the course components is as follows:

1. Lectures: Considered the least challenging aspect of the course.
2. Homework: Slightly more difficult than lectures, but quite useless.
3. Tutorials: Some tutorial questions are taken from homework and past year papers, making them moderately challenging.
4. Past papers: More challenging than tutorials as they provide a comprehensive review of the course material.
5. Actual Exam: The most difficult component, because they know the course is absolute grading and they don't want you to get a grade higher than B range.

Since the grading is absolute, your performance in the course will solely depend on your understanding and preparation.

The following is the rough guideline: A+/A/A- > 85.5 > B+/B/B- >70.5 > C+/C/C- > 50.5 > D > 40
reviews.comment_workload: The workload for this course is relatively light, with only a few assignments every week. These assignments can be attempted unlimited times, so try to get full mark for this.

reviews.author: MarDing
reviews.title: MATH 1013 Course Review
reviews.comment_content:
Ch.1
Review of functions
Representing functions
Inverse, exponential and logarithmic functions
Trigonometric functions and their inverses

Ch.2
The idea of limits
Definitions of limits
Techniques for computing limits
Infinite limits
Limits at infinity
Continuity

Ch.3
Introducing the derivatives
Rules of differentiation
The product and quotient rules
Derivatives of trigonometric functions
Derivatives as rates of change
The chain rule
Implicit differentiation
Derivatives of logarithmic and exponential functions
Derivatives of inverse trigonometric functions
Related rates

Ch.4
Maxima and minima
What derivatives tell us
Graphing functions
Optimization problems
Linear approximation and differentials
Mean value theorem
L'Hopital's rule
Newton's method
Antiderivatives

Ch.5
Approximating areas under curves
Definite integrals
Fundamental theorem of calculus
Working with integrals
Substitution rule


This is an introductory course in one-variable calculus, the first in the Calculus I and II sequence, designed for students that have taken HKDSE Mathematics Extended Module M1/M2. Topics include functions and their limits, continuity, derivatives and rules of differentiation, applications of derivatives, and basic integral calculus. Exclusion(s): AL Pure Mathematics; AL Applied Mathematics; MATH 1003, MATH 1012, MATH 1014, MATH 1018, MATH 1020, MATH 1023, MATH 1024 Prerequisite(s): Level 3 or above in HKDSE Mathematics Extended Module M1/M2
reviews.comment_teaching:
Teaching according to the textbook 'Calculus for Scientists and Engineers (Early Transcendentals) by Briggs, Cochran and Gillett' (Chapter 1 to 5).

TK Lam will do the proving part of the theorem in the lecture lessons. However the textbook has already provides the detail proving with some examples.
TK Lam taught well about the theoretical part but seldom provide practice questions and applications.
reviews.comment_grading:
Absolute grading system.
The following is the rough guideline:
A+/A/A- > 85.5 > B+/B/B- >70.5 > C+/C/C- > 50.5 > D > 40

No marks for attendance.

My result:
Mid-term: 90/100 (35%)
final exam: 79/100 (55%)
Homework: 10/10 (10%)
Overall: 84.95/100
Letter grade: B+
It is so sad that I nearly can get a A- in this course due to the absolute grading system even I got higher than the mean about 20 marks.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is very light that it only requires to do assignments on the WebWork system, which is around 10 assignments totally. The assignments can help you to review the concepts and its applications in various kind of questions. You can submit the answer for several times which will not deduct your marks.

reviews.author: random guy
reviews.comment_content: Functions and their limits, continuity, derivatives and rules of differentiation, application of derivatives and basic integral calculus.
reviews.comment_teaching: The concept are taught in a detailed and clear manner. There will lecture notes and videos uploaded after each lesson, which allow students to catch up even if they miss the lesson.
reviews.comment_grading: The grades are good as most of the concepts and topic have been taught in the HKDSE M1/M2 subject. I got an A for around 90%
reviews.comment_workload: There is only little homework and the deadline is often one month after the release of homework. Also, students have unlimited attempts to the questions in the homework. Even they answer wrongly for a few times, they won't lose their credit and are able to get full marks for the homework.

reviews.author: ppotato
reviews.title: A bit fast pased but okay is you attend lectures and practice
reviews.comment_content: The content was mostly what you have already studied in high school so it's easy to understand.
reviews.comment_teaching: Mr. Lam is a good teacher (though his voice was pretty hard to understand because he speaks relatively low even with a mic). The TA Phyllis Liang was outstanding and I would go as far as to say she's the reason I managed to score whatever grade I could
reviews.comment_grading: The grading was okay I guess. The final and midterm exam was a bit harder than what they taught in class so you have to practice more than what they taught in lectures and tutorials. Please practice T^T. I got a bad grade because I didn't
reviews.comment_workload: The workload was okay. There was homework almost every other week and nothing much just self-study and attending lectures and tutorials.

reviews.author: alanto
reviews.title: Choose MATH1003 if you can
reviews.comment_content:
Topics include:
- Limits
- Finding derivatives (first principles/ rules)
- Finding asymptotes
- Continuity
- Implicit differentiation
- Integration (A little bit only)
All topics are included in the M2 syllabus, except L'Hopital's Rule.
If you were hardworking enough in secondary school, you should be able to handle the course.
reviews.comment_teaching:
It varies greatly between professors.
Indeed, if you want to learn more and obtain a better grade, please don't skip any tutorials. The tutorials could help you gain a better understanding of all the topics.
reviews.comment_grading:
Absolute grading!
The grade depends on how much effort you have put in.
reviews.comment_workload: Practice makes perfect

reviews.author: carooool
reviews.comment_content:
Calculation:intervals and inequalities
functions and graphs, operations on functions, elementary functions, inverse functions
limits of function values and continuity of functions, asymptotes
tangent line equations, derivatives, differentiation rules
derivatives of inverse functions, implicit differentiation, logarithmic differentiation
application of derivatives as rates of change
reviews.comment_teaching: The teacher teaches moderately，more slowly, and explains more carefully. The content is relatively simple, can be self-study, most of the knowledge is learned by senior students, and the task is relatively small
reviews.comment_grading: A
reviews.comment_workload: It takes about 30-40 minutes to do a dozen fill-in-the-blank questions each week, which are relatively easy. The midterm and final periods are moderately difficult, so you can do past paper carefully

reviews.author: sheepy
reviews.title: Normal math course
reviews.comment_content:
Mostly DSE M2 stuff but with more explanation or elaboration on these topic
The first few concepts are quite simple but the later ones are very important

See others for detail
reviews.comment_teaching:
The prof is ok but the lecture is lengthy and sleepy...
I skip quite a few of them for other stuff
The notes in the website is useful enough for understanding

One of the TA is very good and she would give us useful notes
Go for the tutorials for main areas to study and lectures if you want to watch full steps
reviews.comment_grading:
See others for detail

The midterm is kind of like a normal test that you have to do in secondary school but I have no idea what is going on in the final.
If you didn't study or even touch the past paper given (like me), it would be a big problem as the style of the question is pretty similar.
The course is competitive so the grading is quite bad.

*If you are already good in calculus, this should not be a problem.
reviews.comment_workload:
Average workload

-Homework
Mostly one set of problem each 1-2 weeks ,the question is not that hard if you use external tools for help
Sometimes the question requires a very wierd looking answer
And don't copy from others because the variables in your question  differ from others , but ofc you can ask others for help

reviews.author: ytk
reviews.title: Easy to handle
reviews.comment_content:
The content is similar with the secondary school HKDSE M2.
The content include derivatives, integral.

It is easy for M2 people to handle the courses assignments and exams.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Not that clear and useful for M2 people
Always copying from the book and notes
Do webwork is better for understanding the topic
reviews.comment_grading:
absolute grading 4 5 7 85
>=85 A range
70 - 85 B range
50 - 70 C range
40 - 50 D range
<40 Fail

Easy to handle and get B range or above for M2 people

For non-M2 people, it may be a bit hard to compete with M2 guys, yet if you do all the assignments it is achievable to get B range or higher
reviews.comment_workload:
Easy
the workload is not heavy, around 1 webwork assignment per week and the tutorials will always clarify the concepts and help us to finish webwork.

reviews.author: OW1TY2
reviews.comment_content: Section L1 student —— so much more stuff learnt than other secrtions (some important concepts: Mean-Value Theorem, Intermediate Value Theorem, ε-δ definition of limit), not very easy to understand, but definitely funny
reviews.comment_teaching: Humorous teaching style, Professor Fong is also active in his discord group (but he only appears at night).
reviews.comment_grading: All math courses grades by score instead of curve, but to my experience (+1 sd in mid-term and in mean range in final, B), moderate grading.
reviews.comment_workload:
Homework: the questions are not easy but only 1 hw per week and around 10-15 questions per hw, you only need to do 1-3 questions per day.

Mid-term and Final are DIFFICULT ! 3 hours are just enough for the exam so don't waste any time for meaningless actions during exam, and you do need to re-do the hw and do some more other supplementary exercises 2 weeks before exam.

reviews.author: BenHo5021
reviews.title: 正
reviews.comment_content:
just teach you some basic math (it is fact but I don't feel they are easy)
like：IVT、MVT、
How to write Negation、Contrapostive, Converse of the statement
、First Principle
、differentiation formula (some are M2 stuff, some is a little more difficult 啦)
reviews.comment_teaching:
funny既，會講下爛gag，起馬5會悶
教個陣會寫、講清楚步驟，所以都5會跟甩
而且難既題目會畫圖令你更清楚做緊咩
有時講D重點會連講幾次 講到你訓著左都知個重點concept
另外有問題可以試下約Consult 小弟就十分白痴既 用左好一段時間、問多幾次FF 先明個題目 佢會好有耐性甘教你
reviews.comment_grading:
有2種計法

方法1:
HW：20%
Midterm：40%
Final：40%
總共：100%

方法2:
HW：20%
Midterm：5%
Final：70%
總共：95%

建議midterm拎高分D，因為Final只會更難

個人（、同學、阿sir）心得就係：

1.先睇清楚題目given咩比你，留意我最後想要咩結果
2.千萬5好由尾(result)做到頭(given)（prove既題目），要根據題目given既野做到結果
3.5識就試下將睇得明既野畫圖出來先

（4） .千萬5好死記公式，要記得還要記得，但你記得對FInal/Midterm只係一DD作用，你需要既係對concept既理解（因為份卷一半多D題目都係同你之前做既題目/練習5同）

最後我想講 好難讀啊 尸口巾你個肺 但整體而言 如果你鐘意數學 記住讀L1  因為真係好L正
reviews.comment_workload:
HW有11份
第9-11份只會計做0%/60%/80%
而你可以用9-11份其中一份既成績取代第1-8份最差個一份
D功課基本上都係1星期一份 對我來講每份都難到就抽筋
但有上堂同問下TA/FF既話 我諗應該可以每份都8成以上既 5太需要靠第9-11份HW拉分

reviews.author: Cvsvdvdv
reviews.comment_content:
Calculus. Half DSE-M2 stuff, half new things. Good luck if you are M1.
Here's a list(not complete) of non-M2 stuffs in this course:
Continuity, Differentiability, Intermediate Value Theorem, Mean Value Theorem, 'one-to-one' function, Solving problems with absolute functions, Sandwich(Squeeze) Theorem, Linear Approximation, Newton's Method, Critical Point, Rolle's Theorem, L'Hopital Rule, Reimann Sum, Fundamental Theorem of Calculus(A little more things than DSE M2)
reviews.comment_teaching:
Instructors don't matter, the number of monstrous mainland students in your lecture does.

I highly recommend that you:
1. Read James Stweart Calculus 7ed (this course covers part of the book).
2. Finish your homework ASAP, get extra problem sets if you're not confident in a specific chapter.
3. Get yourself prepared for the test by doing pastpaper.
4. MOST IMPORTANT: Know what you're doing. Know how and WHY you're carrying out the calculation in a particular way instead of another.
reviews.comment_grading:
As a M2 student and also in Spring semester (got many non local international students support me),
Got A-
But dont take this course in Spring course if you in Engin or Sci school becuase ir is the pre requisite of many thousands of courses and it will affect your timetable.
reviews.comment_workload:
Large workload. there are 8 web works. And these webworks is also very hard.

If you want to get B/C in your exam , you have to spend so much time in doing the practice.

reviews.author: kimsssssss
reviews.title: 合理龜
reviews.comment_content: 用一個新嘅角度去睇你M2學過嘅嘢，L1比較特別，係比想讀Math嘅人讀，所以會用偏理論去解釋學嘅嘢。學嘅嘢對我嚟講全部都好新，不過只要努力啲都係會明到嘅。
reviews.comment_teaching: FF教得幾好，雖然有時講笑deadair，但講書唔會悶，一堂時間覺得過得好快，加上有心教，可以係落堂後同埋office hour上去問問題。加上TA們都好用心教，係tutorial以外嘅時間都會好樂意答問題。
reviews.comment_grading:
85%A range
60%B range
40%C range
數學course嚟講隻龜算靚
reviews.comment_workload: 雖然可能係我能力問題，但一個禮拜有一份hw，平均每份可能做2-3個鐘，個workload都唔少

reviews.author: Gracy99.b
reviews.title: prof was helpful
reviews.comment_content: prof was very helpful and replied to emails quickly.
reviews.comment_teaching: she had lectures and recordings and if you did not understand the content after the lectures she was very helpful.  No attendance was required for the lectures
reviews.comment_grading:
they were easy on the grading

10% homework WebWork
25% midterm
65% final
all was made pretty easy
reviews.comment_workload: very minimal just a homework every week. If there was an impossible question in the homework she would provide a detailed explanation for the answer and if you still did not understand it she would help you with your specific question too.

reviews.author: worstUSTstudent
reviews.comment_content:
Number and intervals, inequalities and absolutes, functions and graphs, composite functions, exponential functions.
Trigonometric functions, inverse functions, logarithmic functions, inverse trigonometric functions.
Tangent and velocity, the limit of a function, limit laws.
Continuity, limits at infinity and horizontal asymptotes, derivatives and rates of change.
Basic derivatives, product and quotient rules, derivatives of trigonometric functions.
Chain rule, implicit differentiation, derivatives of inverse trigonometric functions and logarithmic functions.
Rates of change problems, related rates.
Linear approximations and differentials, maximum and minimum values.
Mean Value Theorem, derivatives and graphs, L’Hôpital’s rule.
Curve sketching, optimization problems, Newton’s Method.
Antiderivatives, areas and distances.
Definite integrals, the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus.
Applications of integrals, the substitution rule. (sorry)

favourable to people with good grade in DSE M2
reviews.comment_teaching:
I think skipping all lectures is fine as long as you understand the concepts of the course and do past paper.

Both lectures and tutorials do not require attendance.
reviews.comment_grading:
10% Homework
35% Midterm
55% Final

I think is quite decent although I got a super bad grade. It's either because I am dumb or didn't revise much or both. I think it is both.
reviews.comment_workload: Webwork is super easy and you must get 100% of all homework because you have unlimited tries. Webwork also doesn't reflect the difficulty of midterms and finals at all. Please do past papers.

reviews.author: ZYC
reviews.comment_content:
In choronological order:
1. The content is rather simple in the first few weeks, basically about derivatives. Do pay attention to the definition of derivatives (the one that uses limit to express derivatives), usually harder questions in midterm exam come from this knowledge point.

2. Knowledge points whichever relevant to limits are EXTREMELY important!

3. To me, things get harder quickly when it comes to integration. Time seems going really fast in the last few weeks. For those who have no foundation like me, I STRONGLY suggest previewing this part in the first few weeks, as you may have more spare time at that time to practice and digest.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof. Wang is nice! Her notes are neat and clear, her teaching pace is just the way I like (though may be a bit slow for students who are good at maths), and she is very prompt and patient when answering questions. What's more, she do listen to students' needs, as she gave us quite some materials for revision before final in respond to some students' email. As a professor teaching maths, she've already done everything.
She has the ability to explain concepts clear, so no need to search for other online courses.
reviews.comment_grading:
Quite fair.
10% Homework
35% Midterm
55% Final
Questions in homework allow you to submit answers in unlimited times, so it is worthwhlie bringing more patience to finish them perfectly, and raise questions whenever you encounter problem.
Midterm is easy, do avoid making stupid mistakes.
Final is hard, so enough practice is necessary
My grades:
full in homework
Midterm: 85/100 (mean:78.07)
Final: 74/100 (mean:55.68)
Total: 80.45 B+ (mean:67.44)
reviews.comment_workload:
Quite friendly even to year1 students. Nothing more than Webwork assignments.
However, my suggestion is, it is not realistic to get A range if you solely rely on exercise in homework and tutorial. Extra exercise is a must 'cuz competition is fierce.

reviews.author: cyyy
reviews.comment_content: 内容相对于内地的高数差不多，初步地介绍了微积分的相关概念，FONG, Ysz Ho 教授会更加强调逻辑（L1），因此也会对数学思维有相对深入的认识。
reviews.comment_teaching: 教授教的很好，上课会耐心地讲解习题，并且讲话幽默，也会耐心回答问题。
reviews.comment_grading: 这门课也是比较好拿好grade的，只要平时肯花时间去思考总结，并且保证一定的练习，基本都不错。
reviews.comment_workload: 课程压力的话也比较适合，一周一次作业，一般可能用到两三个小时，作业基本都是证明题，一般是一些概念或课堂例题的变式深入

reviews.author: tii
reviews.title: a easy and not easy course
reviews.comment_content:
if you have great score in m2, then this is a easy course just with some new stuff (newton method, mid value theorem)
and this course mostly cover differeniation and integration
reviews.comment_teaching: quite boring, just watch the teacher do maths

reviews.author: smallstring
reviews.title: Work Hard><
reviews.comment_content:
You may be a year 1 student. Don't worry. It will be fine:)
Trust yourself.

Content:
Number and intervals, inequalities and absolutes, functions and graphs, composite functions, exponential functions.
Trigonometric functions, inverse functions, logarithmic functions, inverse trigonometric functions.
Tangent and velocity, the limit of a function, limit laws.
Continuity, limits at infinity and horizontal asymptotes, derivatives and rates of change.
Basic derivatives, product and quotient rules, derivatives of trigonometric functions.
Chain rule, implicit differentiation, derivatives of inverse trigonometric functions and logarithmic functions.
Rates of change problems, related rates.
Linear approximations and differentials, maximum and minimum values.
Mean Value Theorem, derivatives and graphs, L’Hôpital’s rule.
Curve sketching, optimization problems, Newton’s Method.
Antiderivatives, areas and distances.
Definite integrals, the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus.
Applications of integrals, the substitution rule.



If you are a local student who have studied M2, you need to be more careful on the applications on those theorems like mean value theorems, Riemann sum and limits.

If you are a local student who have studied M1, you need to work much harder.

If you did not study integration (積分) in your high school, you should practice integration more before the final exam.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof: CHANG, Huai-Liang (L09)
Before taking this course, I saw a lot of bad reviews about him in the USTspace, scaring me. But after the whole semester, I think he is not really bad, maybe because I am also a boring person(工科直男><).
Somebody may complain about his accent. But if you are familiar with Putonghua, you will definitely know what he is talking about as he came from Taiwan.

TA: Lau Hing Sang (T09C)
He used to be a local secondary school teacher and knew the feeling of year 1 local M2 students well. My tutorial class was in the evening and only a few students attended. As all of us can listen and speak Cantonese (local and mainland students), we can always 談笑風生 in the tutorials.
In the tutorials, he always provided hard copy notes to students. His notes and tutorials were very helpful so you should not miss any of his tutorials.
reviews.comment_grading:
I would say it is far.

Don't be despaired and jealous. These feelings would destroy you. Try your best like you are taking the public exam!

My grade: B

Reference:
HKDSE Math: 5 M2: 5
reviews.comment_workload:
As for the assignments, there is only one homework per two weeks on average. The homework questions are always easy. But if you find a question you don't know how to do, just go to the Math Support Center AS SOON AS POSSIBLE. (Really)

Although the homework is pretty easy, the mid-term and final exam are, haha, you have already known what I mean :D . You should start your revision not later than you receive the past papers. Remember, do all the past papers before the exams. If you find a question you don't know how to do, just go to the Math Support Center AS SOON AS POSSIBLE. (Really)

Therefore, the overall workload is not light. The Organic Chemistry tutor, Khan Academy and Herman Yeung(for local students only) could help you.

reviews.author: Aney
reviews.title: Cool course
reviews.comment_content:
Calculus.

Limits.
Differential calculus (Differentiation).
Integral calculus (Integration).
Multivariable calculus (Function theory).
reviews.comment_teaching: Didn’t attend, Self-study is enough. Find some reference books that are relevant and complete the exercises in the book. Watch some YouTube tutorials with 2x speed is faster than learning those things in lectures.
reviews.comment_grading:
Overall 88/100
A-
Quite easy exam, revise and practice is enough for a high grade.
reviews.comment_workload: 8hw, each takes 2 hours to do, quite easy to full mark. The course encourages discussion with peers so feel free to complete the assignments with bunch of friends for faster submission.

reviews.author: Ningiceland
reviews.comment_content: The notes are quite simple and clear.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof. Lam can explain the content clearly. His writing notes are detailed and published timely after every lesson.
reviews.comment_grading:
Quite good.
I got 97/100 in midterm and 94/100 in final. Additionally, I got full marks in all of my assignments.
The grade turns out to be A+
reviews.comment_workload: I think the workload is quite acceptable as we only need to complete some easy tasks on Webwork. Moreover, these tasks have unlimited trial opportunities. So I think it is Okay to finish them and get a satisfactory result.

reviews.author: 9_9rookie
reviews.comment_content: 整個課程嘅外殼同m2微積分部分幾相似，譬如都係計limt、differentiation、integration，但係詳細嘅內容會多咗唔少，今年黎講，mid-term之前d嘅野會比較似m2 ，主要強調limt、differentiation嘢，而mid-term之後相比起m2嘅微積分部分會多更多嘢，所以唔係話有讀m2就一定掂。
reviews.comment_teaching: prof. Wang比人感覺幾nice，尤其係佢上堂果陣係手寫lecture notes，d 字都好工整，內容亦都充足，但係佢把聲唔係太清楚，上佢堂要坐前d，同埋如果睇recording佢把聲會更加模糊，所以video我都係睇返其他section。
reviews.comment_grading:
abs grade，個人覺得算公平
Grading system:
- WeBWorK Online Homework (10%)
- Midterm Exam (35%)
- Final Exam (55%)
reviews.comment_workload: workload唔算重，對於有讀m2嘅人黎講應該會發現有好多m2有教，d assigment係用webwork做，即係冇步驟，就咁輸入佢要嘅答案就可以。佢通常deadline前兩個禮拜就release咗份嘢，所以你可以提早做，在deadline之前就算做錯都可以無限次改，提早做會輕鬆好多。

reviews.author: aaron1014
reviews.title: The average student's review
reviews.comment_content:
Although the contents of this course were mostly covered in high school, it was designed to be delivered in a more in depth manner (at least compared to my high school calculus). Definitely gave me a better understanding of how calculus works.

Main topics covered:
    - Functions (including composite, exponential, inverse, log, trigonometric)
    - Limits (heavy emphasis on this for the midterms)
    - Differentiation (derivatives, implicit differentiation)
    - Related rates
    - Linear approximation
    - Mean value theorem
    - L'hopital rule
    - Curve sketching (this is a pain in the ass)
    - Optimization
    - Newton's method
    - Integration (Riemann sum)
    - Fundamental theorem of calculus
    - Substitution rule
reviews.comment_teaching:
Class lecturer: Bian Fengmiao

The teacher had a heavy accent when teaching, but she gave amazing digitally hand written lecture notes (both effective and visually appealing). Examples in class cover a large variations of questions to help you grasp the concepts. She teaches by solving pre written questions by hand similar to how math YouTubers do it. The working she does in class are pretty much the content of the lecture notes she provides after the class.

Tutor: LAU Hing Sang

Amazing tutor. Provides you a tutorial sheet with a ton of questions to practice on and has a website for the answers. Discusses a wide variety of questions in the actual tutorial so your time is definitely not wasted. To be honest, there's more value attending this tutor than the actual lectures. Might have graded the teaching lower if not for this tutor.
reviews.comment_grading:
Midterm: 75/100 (Mean: 76.1)
Final: 66/100 (Mean: 59.48)
Total: 72.55/100 (Mean: 68.86)
Letter grade: B

For midterms and finals, I did around 3-4 past papers. Had some careless answers in the exams. Past papers are similar to each other. Overall I think the grading was pretty fair, although I think quite a few would disagree
reviews.comment_workload: The only workload outside of class was the web work homework.It has unlimited attempts. I think it would be nice to find someone who also takes the course to discuss the homework. Overall, I think the workload was light especially if you compare it to other subjects.

reviews.author: plzgimmeA
reviews.comment_content:
Inverse Functions
Continuity of Functions
Implicit Differentiation
Newton's Method
L'Hopital's Rule
Mean Value Theorem
Curve Sketching
Antiderivatives
Fundamental Theorem of Calculus
Substitution Rule

Basically, most of the content was from DSE M1 and M2.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof Lam uses pen and paper to demonstrate examples in class.

He uses the most basic and straightforward examples to demonstrate different concepts, which is good. However, in the exams the questions were much harder than the ones you've practiced in class.

One thing that's important to note down is that Prof Lam's notes are very unorganized and it's quite difficult for me to understand what he's trying to explain.

started self-studying after mid-term. performed much better in finals than in mid-term :P
reviews.comment_grading:
Absolute Grading.

Grade scale:   F < 40% < D < 50% < C's < 70% < B's < 85% < A's

Grading system:
- WeBWorK Online Homework (10%)
- Midterm Exam (35%)
- Final Exam (55%)

Mean for mid-term is around 7x%
Mean for finals is around 5x%
reviews.comment_workload:
It depends on whether you are hardworking or not.

WebWork assignment around once per 2 weeks' time.
Each assignment has around 10 questions and you can finish it with unlimited trials.

You can also try to do some more practice on Classviva. (For the hardworking students)

As a DSE M1 student, I find the concepts easy to understand but the questions are way more complicated than expected.

reviews.author: Ayushd
reviews.comment_content:
- No attendance taken
- The syllabus and the exam covers the fundamentals of Calculus (mainly applicative Calculus)
- The designated textbook is extremely useful. Numerous practise questions are given.
reviews.comment_teaching: The lecture was not very interesting to me as the professor used PPT to teach. The content of PPT has been directly taken from the textbook.
reviews.comment_grading: Scoring a desent grade is easy if you avoid silly mistakes such as calculation error. The invigilator will not tolerate silly errors.
reviews.comment_workload: If you are familiar with the fundamentals of Calculus, then the workload will be pretty less. Weekly assignment will be easy to do if the core concepts are clear. Solving questions from the textbook is beneficial.

reviews.author: Warp Drive
reviews.comment_content: The course title is Calculus for Math Majors so undoubtedly it focuses a lot more on the rigorous definition of limit and there are a number of proof rather than calculation in both of your homework and exams. The content, homework and exams are quite different from other lectures of MATH1013. From my own point of view, it is closer to MATH 1023 rather than other 1013. This course covers contents from limit to derivative. Integration will be taught in 1014L1.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof Frederick Fong is definitely an outstanding teacher. He appreciates the beauty of rigorism of mathematics and emphasizes that in his class from time to time. Although I attended only a few lectures, I was deeply impressed by how clearly the professor illustrates things.
As for the tutorial, I had never attended that but I downloaded every tutorial handouts. They are quite helpful when preparing for the exams.
reviews.comment_grading:
There are two grading schemes.
Scheme A: homework 20%; midterm 40%; final 40% (total 100%)
Scheme B: homework 20%; midterm 5%; final 70% (total 95%)
Obviously you can find that there is a chance to make up if your midterm score is not that satisfactory---but at the expense of losing 5% in your total score anyway. It turned out that except for those who get 0 marks in their midterms, almost no one actually benefits from the Scheme B so midterm is crucial.
Statistics:
midterm: LQ 49; mean 63.78; UQ 81.5; high 100 (total 100)
final: LQ 41; mean 53.13; UQ 68; high 99.5 (total 100)
I got 97.48 in homework, 90 in midterm and 80.5 in final, my letter grade is A- (very close to A)
A range is only 15% with half A-, which, from my own view, is a little harsh considering the difficulty of the exams. But don't worry, the B and C ranges are wide enough.
More detailed statistics is attached.
reviews.comment_workload: The content of the lecture is quite easy. Homework is not on webwork. You need to print it and handwrite. The questions on lecture and tutorial notes along with sample midterm/final are main resources for you to prepare for the exam since there is no past paper. It is a bit annoying since the questions on lecture notes are not with answers so sometimes you need to think for a long time to solve some proof questions. Luckily, the questions in exams are not very difficult but you need to BE CAREFUL ABOUT THE DETAILS in your solution. Sadly, I always skipped some steps or didn't follow the standard step of mathematical induction in exams. So although I got the correct answer or my method of proving is correct, I lost 5~8 points in both exams and it cannot be argued back.

reviews.author: clt
reviews.title: M2 2
reviews.comment_content:
Basically a review of the M2 syllabus but with a bit more stuff extended, like differentiability, IVT, MVT, the latter two are only introduced close to the middle of the course. You can reference other people's reviews for the syllabus. You should be able to handle the concepts if you are versed in M2, though from the other reviews it won't give you a free ticket to a good grade.

1013 leans more on the application of calculus, and less on the rigorous proving side of things. I observed 1023 in this semester, and the difference between them is the application vs proving focus. If you're interested in things akin to https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLjCP7F6SlypXhD8vlv_wP-pZbn_-gZ3sd you might prefer 1023, but for me I just needed to fill the prerequisite with either 1013/1023.
reviews.comment_teaching:
No attendance for tutorials nor lectures. Officially you have to pick a tutorial with matching tutorial numbers with the lectures, but obviously they don't enforce that.

He basically just reads off the notes he gives in canvas. I don't think I got anything out of the lectures, save for the classwork exercises and getting to ask him questions about the notes. Though he is still approachable, after-class or email.
reviews.comment_grading:
Will update after finals, but I got 97% on the midterms with 1 LQ mistake.

A majority of the marks were on MC questions. No calculators are allowed, but there weren't any calculations that warranted a calculator with the large amount of time given to us anyways.
reviews.comment_workload: Completed in WebWork, 1-2 weeks per HW(? don't remember precisely). There is adequate time to read ahead and finish them or wait until the lecturer gets to the topic. Around 10 Qs per HW, math support center is always there if you needed help.

reviews.author: fifio
reviews.comment_content:
1. Number and intervals, inequalities and absolutes, functions and graphs, composite functions, exponential functions.

2.Trigonometric functions, inverse functions, logarithmic functions, inverse trigonometric functions.

3.Tangent and velocity, the limit of a function, limit laws.

4.Continuity, limits at infinity and horizontal asymptotes, derivatives and rates of change.

5.Basic derivatives, product and quotient rules, derivatives of trigonometric functions.

6.Chain rule, implicit differentiation, derivatives of inverse trigonometric functions and logarithmic functions.

7.Rates of change problems, related rates.

8.Linear approximations and differentials, maximum and minimum values.

9.Mean Value Theorem, derivatives and graphs, L’Hôpital’s rule.

10.Curve sketching, optimization problems, Newton’s Method.

11.Antiderivatives, areas and distances.

12.Definite integrals, the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus.

13.Applications of integrals, the substitution rule.

Review of definite integrals and the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus.
Integration by parts, trigonometric integrals, trigonometric substitutions, polar coordinates and calculus, partial fractions.

Taylor polynomials, power series, and Taylor series.
Vectors in two and three dimensions, dot products, cross products.

Continuity, Differentiability, Intermediate Value Theorem, Mean Value Theorem, 'one-to-one' function, Solving problems with absolute functions, Sandwich(Squeeze) Theorem, Linear Approximation, Newton's Method, Critical Point, Rolle's Theorem, L'Hopital Rule, Reimann Sum, Fundamental Theorem of Calculus (credit from previous review, I think it's a good reference)

Make sure to attend tutorial classes as well, a good TA really helps a lot, with exercises and clearing concepts!!!

Generally speaking, I do think attending tutorial is more important than attending lecture. If you have a good TA with good materials and do not skip concepts.
reviews.comment_grading:
Absolute grading system, which makes this course VERY HARD to get a good grade:
85-100%-->A range
70-85%-->B range
50-70%-->C range
40-50%-->D
0-40%-->Fail

Think before you take the course :)
reviews.comment_workload:
Homework:
Basically 1 WebWork(Online homework) per week, each consists of 10-18 questions.

No attendance required for any lecture and tutorials as usual.

Exam: Do your best in the relatively simple mid-term to secure a better grade earlier. All contents will appear in final exam, so really a lot to review before the exam. The questions could be very hard but not undoable.

reviews.author: SATOCHIHIRO
reviews.comment_content:
First half would be quite easy if you had learned some basic knowledge in your secondary school, no sequence limit.
It will start with inequalities and basic elementary functions in the first month.

Second half showed Linear approximation, Newton's method and we focused on the application of differential. Then the Indefinite integral, Definite integral(Integration By Substitution) ,Fundamental Theorem of Calculus, basic level of Riemann sum.
reviews.comment_teaching: The instructor will carefully teach the differentiation in a baby's baby level. Although his English is not very fluent, reading the board is enough since knowledge itself is quite simple. Tutorial class is quite important since your TA would give you some tips or show the process of some questions in your homework. Some of the example questions would harder than your hw but similar to final's difficulty.
reviews.comment_grading:
Absolute grading in this sem.
10% Assignments, 35%Midterm, 55%Final
>93.5A+
88.5A
83.5A-
78.5B+
72.5B
...
Get in A range is quite easy but A+ is not. In this semester we had 10 MC in midterm and I got 90/100. In final I got 92/100 and A+ (MC and about 4 questions you need to write some process).  All of them were similar to the homework and PP but relatively harder in this sem.
reviews.comment_workload: Easy questions, but the last assignment was relatively complex when I did some of the integrations. The assignment had no submission limit in this sem.

reviews.author: HC123
reviews.comment_content:
I am having online-class, all contents are taught online.
Most of the content materials have been taught during the high school so it is easier to catch up if you missed some of the classes.
Although the materials seems easy, the exam is difficult.

Content:
1. Number, inequalities and absolutes, basic functions and graphs, composite functions
2. Trigonometric functions, inverse functions, logarithmic functions, inverse trigonometric functions
3. Tangent and velocity, the limit of a function, limit laws
4. Continuity, limits at infinity and horizontal asymptotes, derivatives and rates of change
5. Basic derivatives, product and quotient rules, derivatives of trigonometric functions
6. Chain rule, implicit differentiation, derivatives of inverse trigonometric functions and logarithmic functions
7. Rates of change problems, related rates
8. Linear approximations and differentials, maximum and minimum values
9. Mean Value Theorem, derivatives and graphs, L’Hôpital’s rule
10. Curve sketching, optimization problems, Newton’s Method
11. Antiderivatives, areas and distances
12. Definite integrals, the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus
13. Indefinite integrals and net change, the substitution rule
reviews.comment_teaching:
Mr. Yang, Hui is a good teacher and is willing to teach you if you ask him question.

If you look at other's review, it is true that his English PRONUNCIATION is problematic. However, you will still be able to understand the material because he write everything what he has just said. He also write everything exactly the same to the other notes that has been uploaded, which I think I can read it by myself. There is NO additional explanation that is important.
reviews.comment_grading:
Homework  25%
Final           75%
NO attendance.

Mean is 68,...% ("..." means "I forgot").

I did ALL of the homework.
My score is 65%.
Grade is B-

Even though I did all homework, I thought I will get at least B.
I would say grading is bad, so do not mess up your final.
reviews.comment_workload:
8 Homework (No written homework, but web-work).

Some of the work require a very longtime to deal with, so make sure you start doing it at least 3 days before the deadline. A similar solution is available in internet.

reviews.author: Billy Ngai
reviews.comment_content:
Half DSE-M2 stuff, half new things..
Here's a list(not complete) of non-M2 stuffs in this course:
Continuity, Differentiability, Intermediate Value Theorem, Mean Value Theorem, 'one-to-one' function, Solving problems with absolute functions, Sandwich(Squeeze) Theorem, Linear Approximation, Newton's Method, Critical Point, Rolle's Theorem, L'Hopital Rule, Reimann Sum, Fundamental Theorem of Calculus(A little more things than DSE M2)
reviews.comment_teaching: Just repeating the notes.When I first go to tutorial,there was only 2 people in the classroom.After that, I never attend tutorial again
reviews.comment_grading: Above mean0.5 sd,get a B
reviews.comment_workload: About 10 assignment,time-consuming but not hard

reviews.author: Sune
reviews.comment_content:
So first, from DSE M2, limits, differentiation, very minimal integration, and the trigonometry things.

Then Linear Approximation, MinMax values of a function, Mean Value Theorem, Graphing, L'Hopital's Rule, Sketch curves, Newton's Method, Antiderivatives, Areas and Disatances, Definite Integrals, Fundamental Theorem of Calculus, Substitution Rule, Applications of Integrals.

I may have skipped some stuff but the above are the more important stuff.

Do not underestimate the content, they seem semi-easy in the first month, but then the difficulty ramps up like walking up a giraffe's back.
reviews.comment_teaching:
For this lecturer, you wanna know her teaching quality?
Imagine a normal teaching, then throw that all out the window.
Her accent is questionable, You would really have to focus to comprehend what she is saying. However, it's not really that difficult because you have the PowerPoint slides as subtitles.
To be fair, she would happily answer any of your questions and her 1-on-1 helping is infinitely better than her lecturing.
reviews.comment_grading:
HW 10%
Midterm 35%
Final 55%

Our midterm this year was 10 MCs, that's it, 10 multiple choice questions. Get one wrong you lose 10%, i.e. 3.5 marks in the final grade.
Finals was 18 MCs(not counting the one that asks you what version your paper is) and 3 LQs, it was a bit more bearable, with MC bearing 54 marks and LQ 46.

OH YES DON'T FORGET ONE THING: NO CALCULATORS IN MIDTERM & FINALS.

I screwed up (failed, got 30%) my midterm, did better in finals and full marks in HW and got a C+ at the end.

Do not underestimate the difficulty of the exam, try to find past papers elsewhere and definitely do the sample paper, but remember the actual is wayyyy harder than the sample paper.
reviews.comment_workload: Not that much, we had HW on classviva, and they allow infinite tries with no penalty, so you can try and try and try. I do have to warn that the HW gets more tough near the end of the semester though, so you should always start early because there's almost no way you're deadline fighting the assignments if you wanna get full mark on HW (which I recommend anyone to do so).

reviews.comment_teaching:
His teaching is really bad with extremely strong accent.
His even taught wrong methods and concepts in lesson and send an apology later by the announcement in Canvas.

Attendance is not required.

Lectures are useless and Tutorial is quite useful.
Lectures are all about math theorems, and actually just so few people understand what is he teaching.
reviews.comment_grading:
Ready to get C range if you are not very good at math.

Sample papers of Midterm and Final Exam is useless, the real exam is much more difficult than the sample one.

Grading:
Online homework in Classviva: 10%
Midterm Exam: 35%
Final Exam: 55%
reviews.comment_workload:
Totally 8 Homework, each consist of around 18 questions.
Some questions are quite complicated and not mentioned in class. The only good thing in this course is that there are unlimited chance to retry the online homework in Classviva, you can resubmit until you got all full marks.

reviews.author: Yippppp
reviews.comment_content: It covers quite a lot of dse m2 content, but learning m2 in high-school definitely is not enough to secure good grade in the course.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The professor will use his own pad to illustrate examples which are quite detailed.
He will also stress on the proof and definition of different theorem in order to let students have a clearer understanding.
Moreover, he is willing to stop whenever someone is not getting the points.
He is passionate to solve any questions raised by students at any time of the lesson.
reviews.comment_grading: The grading of this course is absolute grading, which means even if u higher than the mean 1x marks, you can only get a B, whereas other maths courses are mainly grade by curve.
reviews.comment_workload: It is okay workload, some online exercise which allow infinite attempts. So you can repeat it until you get 100.

reviews.author: Kaisa
reviews.title: Great prof
reviews.comment_content:
Before midterm knowledge is covered by middle school lesson.
The knowledge is not difficult to understand but you need time to practice and skillfully use them.

Tutorial practice is useful. Just download and do it by yourself.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof LI is really great. He explained evrything clearly and lead you to think about the questions step by step by yourself. Since the textbook is written by him, most examples given in lectures are same as textbook. However, you should not miss lectures since some important explanation is helpful for your progress and problem solving ability.
reviews.comment_grading:
Absolute grading.
10% by online homework(Unlimited attempt so you can correct until get full marks)
35% by midterm exam
55% by final exam
No attendance
Midterm is disaster since there is only 10 MC and you lose ten marks per mistake...if you make more than one mistakes in midterm like me, you can never expect a A+ since the total score cannot reach 93.5(A+line)
midterm:80/100(mean 61.92)
final:96(mean 73.14)
total grade:90.8(mean 71.35)
Final grade:A
reviews.comment_workload:
Fair workload.
Online homework get increasingly difficult, and do not worry too much if you cannot finish homework 7 or 8 easily. Most students get great pain here and final exam is not as difficult as them.
I really regretted missing lectures before midterm. Just go to lectures(WeiPing's lecture is great), do homework carefully and review before exam. Do enough past papers and you will find it easy.

His accent is quite hard to understand.
He's an extremely boring teacher and his English is not good. He speaks softly and seems confused sometimes.

poor grading
Absolute grading
Grading is not too strict but it depends on how well the class has performed.

nd you can try a lot of times given the unlimited attempts, most of the questions are quite easy, some questions if you don't know, you can ask friends studying at 1013 or simply go to math support centre.

reviews.author: Mr.a
reviews.comment_content: All about calculus. M2 background is preferred. ~30% of the content is learnt in M2. There will be much more theorems and extensions about calculus. Basically the whole M2 syllabus is included, except for the volume calculation.
reviews.comment_teaching:
She has a strong mainland accent and inaccurate pronunciation. She just basically reads the slides word by word every lesson. Paying attention during the lectures is not helping. I self-study the whole course just by doing ex and reading slides.

The tutorials are better than the lectures. The TA makes her own notes and explains the question in it explicitly. She will post the answers after every lesson. It's not hard to follow the pace of the tutorials as well.

PS attendance not counted in tutorials
reviews.comment_grading:
Homework: 10%
Midterm: 35%
Final: 55%

Midterm has 10 mc questions only. Final has 19 mc questions and 3 long questions. No calculator is allowed in both exams.

Grading is good to me. I got full in hw, 90% in midterm and 97% in final, overall 94.85%, got an A+. Didn't expect that good.

For your reference, I got level 5 in M2 and 5* in compulsory part.
reviews.comment_workload: Depends on how hard you work. If you want to get a good grade, you should do some questions in the question bank in classviva. Homework is not extremely hard. You can have unlimited tries, so 100% in hw shouldn't be hard.

reviews.author: Wai Ching
reviews.title: DSE M2 did not help much for this course. Pastpaper is beneficial. How smart you are greatly affect your performance
reviews.comment_content: Lots of review on some DSE M2 as the course was slanted to M2 rather than M1. Although many content overlapped with M2, the questions in mid-term and final exam were not straight forward. Some even indirectly asked for the fundamentals of the content like testing the understandings of derivatives by providing graphs that seemed to be irrelevant with the course materials. It would help if you complete past papers or tutorials questions as they seemed alike. The questions were in identical format.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Lecturer Jin was so patient in explaining the details which I appreciate but this might be a drawback. He allowed students to interrupt if students could not hear or understand the contents immediately. Some students repeatedly asked some silly questions even if Jin had already answered. I could not stand it as mid-term and exam did not cover those. Therefore I did not attend any lectures after mid-term.

TA Phyllis taught the questions in detail, basically step-by-step. Attend the tutorials if you like to listen the details. But I was reluctant to attend them except the first month as answers were provided a week later. Therefore I completed it by myself and checked the answers when provided.

All lectures/tutorials did not count attendance so I would not recommend attending them or not.
reviews.comment_grading:
Classviva Homework:10%
Mid-term:35%(10 MCs)
FInal:55%(18MCs & 3LQs)

Please refer to the attachment for the statistics and my grades.

For mid-term, although it only consisted of 10MCs, they required understanding the basics rather than memorising the question types.

For final exam, MCs were similar to those in mid-term, LQs were straight forward but if you failed to study some specific part, you could not complete it(I did not study/understood Riemann Sum and Newton method thus losing quite a lot of marks)

Be careful with the questions as they were kinda tricky due to subtle changes with the wordings.
reviews.comment_workload:
For homework it was not heavy as unlimited attempts allowed and answers may be available online by copying the whole question to search on Internet with detailed explanations.

For revision even if you were familiar with the question types and the content, it may not be easy since variations plus cross topics were possible in tests and final. It greatly depends on your flexibility between concepts. Even for MCs it took a lot of time for some questions, especially no calculators allowed for assessments.

Final: 81/100
Total: 79.X (B+)
reviews.comment_workload: Very light if you just wanna get C to B- range since it is absolute grading. However, you should be more hard-working if you wanna get an A [but I have failed :( ]

reviews.author: yyyycccwww
reviews.comment_content: This is an introductory course in one-variable calculus, the first in the Calculus I and II sequence, designed for students that have taken HKDSE Mathematics Extended Module M1/M2. Topics include functions and their limits, continuity, derivatives and rules of differentiation, applications of derivatives, and basic integral calculus.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Not very sure about his teaching as I did not attend his lecture classes, I am not even sure who the professor is :)

But I did attended the tutorial session, tutorial is somewhat useful as it provides an opportunity to you to do some maths and know what could be asked in the exam.
reviews.comment_grading:
Probably absolute grading, perhaps a slight variation between sub-grades.

10% homework (classviva)
35% mid-term exam
55% final exam
reviews.comment_workload: 8 classviva assignments with unlimited attempts, so you can easily score full marks. No other homeworks or projects so the workload is relatively small.

reviews.author: 1qww
reviews.comment_content: Just a revision of what you have learnt in the secondary school M2 lesson. Include topics like limit, integration and differentiation.
reviews.comment_teaching: Wang, Fan is actually quite good at explaining but his English is not enough to let people concentrate on his lecture. You may just feel sleepy in his class.
reviews.comment_grading:
If you want to get a good grade in this course, you will have to be super careful. As midterm only has 10 multiple choice questions, one mistake is having 3.5% of the final marks which is approximately half a subgrade. After revision quite hard, I just eventually get an A-.
Absolute grading:

67.5 B-

reviews.comment_workload: There is like one homework every two weeks. The homework is actually quite easy to finish although maybe one or two questions may use a lot of time to think.

reviews.author: skyfundjr
reviews.comment_content: The content is basically 99% similar with AP Calculus. It would be very helpful if you learned it on your high school.
reviews.comment_teaching: I can see that the professor is trying his best to teach as many materials as he can. However, many students suffer with his English pronunciation. He even has problem with pronouncing F(x)...
reviews.comment_grading: The grading for the workload is great since you can repeat infinitely for your homework. However, for mid-term and final...You should put a lot of effort to receive the grades that you want
reviews.comment_workload: Although the workload is quite heavy, I gave B since you can try as many time as you want. The grading for the workload is based on your highest grade, not the average of your attempts.

reviews.author: Vincentchan9839
reviews.title: I hate absolute grading! :(
reviews.comment_content:
Here is the schedule:

Week one: Wednesday (Sep 1)
-Numbers and intervals, inequalities and absolute values
-Functions and graphs, composite functions

Week two: Monday (Sep 6)
-Exponential functions
-Inverse functions, logarithms, trigonometric functions and inverse trigonometric functions

Week three: Monday (Sep 13)
-Tangent and velocity
-The limit of a function, limit laws

Week four: Monday (Sep 20)  (Holiday: Sep 22)
-Continuity
-Limits at infinity and horizontal asymptotes
-Derivatives and rates of change

Week five: Wednesday (Sep 27)  (Holiday: Oct 1)
-Basic derivatives
-Product and quotient rules

Week six: Tuesday (Oct 4)
-Derivatives of trigonometic functions
-Chain rule
-Implicit differentiation, derivatives of inverse trigonometric functions and logarithmic functions

Week seven: Monday (Oct 11)  (Holiday: Oct 14)
-Rates of change problems
-Related Rates

Week eight: Monday (Oct 18)
-Linear approximations and differentials
-Maximum and minimum values

Midterm Exam: Oct 24 (Sunday), 10:00-12:00

Week nine: Monday Oct 25)
-Mean Value Theorem
-Derivatives and the shape of a graph
-L'Hopital's rule

Week ten: Monday (Nov 1)
-Curve sketching
-Optimization problems
-Newton's method

Week eleven: Monday (Nov 8)
-Anti-derivatives
-Areas and distances
-Definite integrals

Week twelve: Monday (Nov 15)
-The Fundamental Theorem of Calculus
-Average Value of a function

Week thirteen: Monday (Nov 22)
-Applications of integrals
-Substitution rule

Study Break: Dec 1-6
Final Exam Period: Dec 7-18
reviews.comment_teaching:
I attend the pure online mode of this course despite I am in Hong Kong in this semester.

Professor Jin's teaching is acceptable. He is still a nice guy.

He uses his iPad Pro to copy the content from the textbook and illustrate the example to us.

Sometimes his accent is hard to understand and I have to ask him to repeat before I can understand.

He can answer my questions clearly each time I ask him through email or face-to-face.

However, the teaching of the TA is barely acceptable.

The TA is called SHI, Zhongyi. He is really boring and I can hardly understand what he said. The interaction level is really low that we are just watching how he uses his iPad to demonstrate the application of the mathematics skills we learn in class in some extremely difficult questions that will never appear in both mid-term exam and final exam.
reviews.comment_grading:
I can only describe this in one word: DISASTER!

I HATE absolute grading policy in this course! 😡

Grading policy:
-Assignment: 10%
-Mid-term exam: 35%
-Final exam: 55%

Here are some statistics (I only have the average mark) :
-Assignment 1: 88.46/100
-Assignment 2: 94.25/100
-Assignment 3: 92.94/100
-Assignment 4: 88.93/100
-Assignment 5: 85.03/100
-Assignment 6: 90.4/100
-Assignment 7: 82.19/100
-Assignment 8: 85.88/100
-Mid-term exam: 56.88/100
-Final exam: 63.34/100
-Overall: 63.6/100


My result:
-all assignments full mark
-Mid-term exam:60/100
-Final exam:75/100
-Overall:72.25/100

Grade: B-

I expect I can still get B with this score. Unfortunately, the grading of this course is really BAD!

You can see if you get mean, the grade you will get is C+ to C. Very DISAPPOINTING grading method!
(Here is the website to check your result:
https://www.math.ust.hk/intranet/grading/student/
)

:(

For your reference, here are my 2021 HKDSE exam results in mathematics related subject:

Mathematics (Core): Level 5*
Mathematics (M2): Level 5

You can see that there are much more Mathematics elites than I have expected are studying in MATH1013. If your mathematics is bad, then I can only say, "Good luck.".
reviews.comment_workload:
There are only 8 assignments, 1 mid-term exam and 1 final exam.

Each assignment contains about 10 to 20 questions. Some of them are very easy and some of them are quite hard. Each assignment takes you 1 to 2 hours to complete.

The mid-term exam contains 10 MC questions only. (Difficulty level: Moderate)

The final exam contains 18 MC questions and 3 long questions. (Difficulty level: Moderate to Hard)

You need to do more revision if you want good grade. I get a bad grade because I do too little revision.

reviews.title: How you perceive the course mostly depends on your previous calc background
reviews.comment_content:
Please have a look at the course schedule file I attached below.

In general, the course mostly covers basic calculus topics: functions, limits and some related problems, derivatives and many related problems, integration (only u-sub, integration by parts is in MATH1014).

How hard this course is mainly depends on your previous background. If you have been through a math-heavy curriculum like M1/M2 (or like most Asian countries' curriculum), the concepts will be familiar to you and only revising for exercises is needed (tbh, the hardest questions on MATH1013 exams are still easier than some questions on my national high school graduation exam in math). Otherwise, chances are that you may struggle, but self-studying through Youtube or Khan Academy may be really helpful.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Teaching was a bit boring (maybe since I've already dealt with these contents in high school) but in general prof Wang seems to be among the better instructors.

Indeed, in the lectures, the prof goes through the contents and exercises at a steady pace so it is not hard to catch up with her. Her notes are really detailed and organized. She has a mainland accent but generally easy to follow. Prof. Wang is also really nice, so a bit sad that only about 1/3 students regularly attend her lectures.

Tutorials were not as good as the tutor in my section organizes his notes poorly (he writes and draws everything using his bad handwriting, so the notes look quite unattractive, especially the graphs). His accent is bad. The only good thing about tutorials is that there are more advanced exercises not covered during lectures, which you can utilize for self-studying (though a few problems in exams can be even more difficult than that)
reviews.comment_grading:
Assignments: 10%
Midterm: 35%
Final: 55%

Assignments (on Classviva): unlimited attempts are permitted, so basically free points for everyone. There might be hard questions, which you might want to consult with your friends, ask your tutor/prof or go to the Math Support Centre to get help for.

Midterm in previous years have a mix of MCs and long questions, but for my year there were only 10 MCs, so 1 mistake can cost you 3.5 points in the final grade. I also agree with previous reviews that there should be more questions in the midterm.

The final exam has a mix of MCs and long questions (for my year, 19 MCs and 3 long questions). Not too difficult. I finished everything, reviewed all the questions and submitted after just 2 hrs.

Previous reviews suggest that this course uses absolute grading.

My scores:
Assignments: 100 (mean: 92.85)
Midterm: 90 (mean: 57.79)
Final: 97 (mean: 66.44)
Total: 94.85 (mean: 66.05)
Grade: A+
reviews.comment_workload:
Pretty light if you have studied calc in high school, the only things requiring attention are to do the Classviva assignments before deadline and to put some effort into reviewing advanced exercises (especially the ones from past papers). I personally didn't even review at all in the days leading to the final exams :D

If you haven't had any idea of calc before, more effort might be needed.

reviews.author: jerry_nguyen
reviews.title: Bad Instructor
reviews.comment_content:
Please refer to other comments. Basically the same with MATH 1012, calculus, and stopped at Integral.

The content is quite a lot, in my opinion.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Miss Qin's teaching style is too bad, not to say is the worst. She sighed too much, and she just read from slides. Her explanation is hard to understand, and her English accent is hard to comprehend. She should study LANG 1002 to improve her English accent.

If you want to study, recommend Dr TK Lam's class. Dr Lam's teaching is the best in this course.

If you want to self-study, you just randomly pick a section.

TA's is good. Miss Xueyang always replies my email, and her English is near native. Should study in her class if you need assistance.

reviews.author: abcdefghijklmno
reviews.title: M1 student dun be too scared of this course
reviews.comment_content: This course mainly focus on limit and differentiation. There are topics like domain, limits, rate of change ,graph sketching ,Riemann sum ,etc. Almost all of them are new to M1 student. As a M1 student, I would say it is quite hard to catch up in the very beginning. But if you do all the assignments by yourself, you will eventually be familiar with these topics.
reviews.comment_teaching: No attendance. There is no need to attend the Math lessons at all. In fact I have never attended his lessons since the start of October. It is highly recommended to learn from Youtube videos and do the homework in advance. It is way more efficient than listening to his boring, slow teaching style. In fact, I solve most of the problems on homework by watching youtube videos or searching in textbook instead of listening to him or his TA

reviews.comment_workload: workload is not that high compare to other courses. Homework has unlimited attempts so its depends on whether you want to get good grade or not. Will be quite chur during the mid term period but there is only one mid term so i think that's fine.

reviews.author: happystar
reviews.title: Really bad score design - mid term = everything!
reviews.comment_content:
Syllabus:
1.  limit ( which dse m2 does not cover a lot)
2. differentiation
3. basic integration (excluding integrate by part, trigo substitution those m2 stuff)
4. some math theorem like mean value thm, intermediate value thm

Generally, the content is not that difficult, if you have taken m2, then everything should be all fine.  Pay more attention to limit part, really requires carefulness and m2 has little coverage on it.

( my mid-term die because of limit...)
reviews.comment_teaching:
The teaching of math profs or tutors is generally not very useful. But it is understandable.

Remember don't expect too much from prof, they are worked for research, not for teaching.

Highly suggested to learn by yourselves, which is much more efficient than attending lectures.~
reviews.comment_grading:
Rubbish grading.
Mid-term = everything, could it really distinguish student math ability or just test carefulness? Let us see this list:

from my 2 fd- mid term decide your score!
mid term:
90 ~ A
80 ~ A-
70~ B+ (me...)

BUT
mid term - 10MC only  (35%!!!!!!!!!)
final ~ 19 MC  3 LQ    (55% only...)

and note that the final is not that difficult, so cannot make a big difference with others. So losing more than 2 marks in mid-term is equivalent to no A. And for mid-term, it is all about carefulness.

My mark:
midterm: 70/100 (mean: 57.12)
final: 87/100   (mean: 69.27)
overall: 82.35 (mean: 67.34)
(83.5 have A-................)

B+ finally.......................

Finally, give you a cut off (not sure) for your reference:
>93.5 A+
88.5 A
83.5 A-
78.5 B+
72.5 B
67.5 B-
61.5 C+
54.5 C
47.5 C-
38 D
<38 F

The final tip to every freshman:

UST is big pressure, not because the things learned are difficult, but because the grading system is very harsh. Remember to take every mark that you can take because it really makes a difference if you want to get A,

不要輕視mid term, 你會後悔的！！！！！！

reviews.author: non
reviews.comment_content:
limit, differential, integral

some trigonometric function
reviews.comment_teaching:
The instructor has a heavy accent.

And there are many mistakes in her notes, including typos and even confusing description of important concepts (I didn't notice that until I got a wrong answer in hw and check TA's notes)

TA (LIANG, Shixin) is very nice. It seems that she has been TA for many years. She will help you review some concept, and more importantly, supplement some TRICKs and exercise problems. So tutorial classes are of great help.
reviews.comment_grading:
Since it's a fundamental course, the overall grade should be good(A range is easy), but A+ is kind of difficult.

Midterm : 10 MC problem, total 100 scores, 10 each. 35% in total. Please prepare well for it, cuz only 1 or 2 mistakes may keep you away from A+.

Final : relatively better, about 20+ MC, 3 long question(some have partial credits). The points of each problem are smaller, so it allows you to make more(relatively) mistakes.

If you want to get A+, you have to get as high score as you can (i.e, 90/100, 95+/100, etc. I don't know the exact data).
reviews.comment_workload:
Theoretically, the workload is very small.

However, since problems in Midterm and Final exams will be much more difficult than hw and class, you are highly recommended to do some exercise for yourself. As mentioned before, you can go through those problems in TA's notes, which are actually from past paper(I suppose).

reviews.author: Danihaha
reviews.comment_content: content is mainly about DSE m2 stuff, not that difficult. you better do excise rather than understand the whole content. No need to comprehend the entire content and theory, try to understand how to do the question step by step
reviews.comment_teaching: Quite good, seems the best teacher in math1013. Well education with well organization
reviews.comment_grading: absolute grading. quite hard to attain A range.

reviews.author: DAFL
reviews.comment_content: The content is really good and it contains the basic knowledge that you will use in the future. So someone who have studied those knowledge in their high school will master the content easily.
reviews.comment_teaching: I can understand almost all the content in class.
reviews.comment_grading: Is really good because the final exam is easy, I had one wrong choice in the final exam and I got  A+ finally, I think less than one wrong choice can get A+, and two wrong choices can get A.
reviews.comment_workload: Only homework on classviva and is easy

reviews.author: ThomasTse
reviews.comment_content: Syllabus: If you have taken HKDSE M1/M2, over 50% of curricula will be taught as you learned in your high school. Yet, you still have to revise, or else you still will fail your exam/midterm since many things to be taught are much more complicated than the HKDSE syllabus.
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor has the greatest skills to satisfy students' desire to sleep. If you have sleep deprivation, MATH 1013 will be a good course for you to have adequate rest to improve your physical health. Moreover, if you like math in HKDSE, you will not like math at university, since boring teaching style.
reviews.comment_grading:
There is fair grading since the university uses similar exam papers to be allocated to different students. It ensures the fair among students and it confirms academic integrity. Besides, one of the good points this course has is you can input your answer in Classviva, where you do your math homework, without limited opportunities. You can try unlimited times to ensure your homework is 100 marks before due. This makes that you can be easier to have a good grade in Math 1013.

However, things taught in tutorials and lectures and in notes are not enough for you to have a good grade in the course. If you want to have a good grade, I recommend you to find some group to find helps instead of revising alone.
reviews.comment_workload: If you are smart or have well prepared in HKDSE M2. The first few weeks(1-4) will be a good grade. However, when it comes to midterm exams, you will find that these you did and practiced in your homework and tutorial are not synonyms in mid-term exams or final exams. After those few weeks,  you will find that workload comes up.

reviews.author: Vincent_233
reviews.comment_content: This course mainly teaches limits, derivatives, differentiation and integration. However, students who have studied in mainland may have more advantages than others as the content of this is quite similar to what we have learnt in high school . Attendance is not required for both lectures and tutorial sessions, but I will suggest you to attend both, especially the tutorial sessions, as handouts will be distributed.
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor who taught me did provide notes to students during lectures, still, I jotted all the things he had written on the whiteboard. Also, the notes in tutorial sessions are quite useful.
reviews.comment_grading: It uses curve grading, so it really depends on how students studying the same course with you perform.
reviews.comment_workload: There is webwork assignment every week and it consists of about 10 questions in each assignment. I will suggest visiting the Math Support Centre if you have any problems regarding the content as once you lost track, it is hard to catch up with the content in the following lectures.

Fair.
