reviews.author: WallKerSSS
reviews.comment_content:
Similar to m2. NO PROVE at all!
This is an introductory course in one-variable calculus. Topics include functions and graphs, limits of functions and continuity, derivatives and their applications, basic indefinite and definite integrals. Upon successful completion of this course, students should be able to: 1. develop basic computational skills in calculus; 2. express quantitative relationships using the language of functions; 3. apply the concepts and methods of calculus in modeling and problem solving.

Reading Materials:

Jishan Hu, Weiping Li and Yueping Wu. "Calculus for scientists and engineers with MATLAB". [Classviva]
James Stewart. "Single variable calculus: Early transcendentals". Cengage Learning, 2015. [Amazon]
reviews.comment_teaching:
ACCENT is not clear. HE will try his best to answer your question.
TUTORIAL is useful and important. DON'T MISS.
reviews.comment_grading:
15% Classviva 75% Final

85-100%-->A range
70-85%-->B range
50-70%-->C range
40-50%-->D
0-40%-->Fail

NO calculator during the exam. NO worry. NOT MUCH computations
reviews.comment_workload:
HW..   1 per week(Classviva), each consists of 10-18 questions. You will need 1-2hours to finish one, not very heavy workload.  Can attempt questions infinitely many times .
No attendance required for any lecture and tutorials

DON'T FORGET TO DO YR HW!

reviews.author: LuckyTiger
reviews.title: Nice teacher
reviews.comment_content: Please refer to other people for content.
reviews.comment_teaching:
firstly, this guy really knows how to zoom. he used an iPad and wrote up clear and concise notes for students. His proofs didn't miss any step. To this day I still remember the time when he taught about the idea of slope of tangent and limits and finally know how the hell they are supposed to be linked. I felt like a true mathematician and at the same time a fraud that managed to DSE M2 without knowing what slope of tangent is supposed to be. I believe I still remember how to associate them

Also I remember that he said something like don't be fixated on grades you get on this course because in years you could be a master mathematician. That made me respect him much more.

I think a funny thing is sometimes how scientifically he speaks. Like he uses some hard words like auxiliary, rigorous, etc.  It might be tricky for some students, lol
reviews.comment_grading:

reviews.author: susan72
reviews.comment_content:
Week

Topics

1

Number and intervals, inequalities and absolutes, functions and graphs, composite functions, exponential functions.

2

Trigonometric functions, inverse functions, logarithmic functions, inverse trigonometric functions.

3

Tangent and velocity, the limit of a function, limit laws.

4

Continuity, limits at infinity and horizontal asymptotes, derivatives and rates of change.

5

Basic derivatives, product and quotient rules, derivatives of trigonometric functions.

6

Chain rule, implicit differentiation, derivatives of inverse trigonometric functions and logarithmic functions.

7

Rates of change problems, related rates.

8

Linear approximations and differentials, maximum and minimum values.

9

Mean Value Theorem, derivatives and graphs, L’Hôpital’s rule.

10

Curve sketching, optimization problems, Newton’s Method.

11

Antiderivatives, areas and distances.

12

Definite integrals, the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus.

13

Applications of integrals, the substitution rule.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor Ji is a very patient teacher. He gave detailed explanation to the content. He was always willing to answer our questions. So you can raise any question to him.
reviews.comment_workload:
Around 12 assignment.

You can do them repeatedly.
So no worries to get full marks.

Most of the students gained full marks.

reviews.author: khkht
reviews.comment_content:
All about Calculus.
Most topics such as:
- Finding derivatives by first principles
- Limits
- Finding asymptotes
- Continuity
- Implicit differentiation
are covered in the M2 syllabus
There are not a lot of new concepts introduced near the end of the semester which were not covered in the M2 syllabus such as L'Hopital's Rule. If you have been hardworking enough while in secondary school, you should be able to handle the course fairly easily.
reviews.comment_teaching: CAI Yuan spoken English is quite hard to understand.
reviews.comment_grading:
absolute grading
no mid-term  
webwork 25%
final exam 75%

85-100%-->A range
70-85%-->B range
50-70%-->C range
40-50%-->D
0-40%-->Fail

ME: 82% -->B+
reviews.comment_workload: Nearly one webwork per week. Each webwork contain about 10-15 questions.

reviews.author: solarski22
reviews.comment_content: Basic Calculus. A bit hard for DSE M1 students to follow.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor Li is good at teaching. I think he explained the knowledge quite well. Reg in his class will be a wise choice. Sometimes he will teach quite fast, especially if you are a M1 student. He is nice and you can always email him directly to ask him questions. He is patient and will explain clearly. Although sometimes he may not give you the full answer, it is still a good opportunity to learn. In zoom semester, he used his iPad to write his notes, and he will upload his handwritten notes later on. I think it is not enough by just reading his notes, you have to read the textbook at the same time. I think for M1 students, you can try to start reading the textbook (can be found online, or maybe you can try the attached notes below) or start to review the calculus part of your M1 syllabus. Prof Li is really a good professor, I remember he posted an additional zoom lecture for students who have not learnt  radian measures (in DSE M2 only).

The TA, Leung Ho Ming is also good. You can use Cantonese to ask him in his MSC hours, and he will explain it clearly. It is good to attend his tutorials before doing HW. His tutorials notes are useful too.
reviews.comment_grading:
This semester's exam is held online. No midterm. Only final and assignments counts towards your final grade. Scoring full marks in your homework will your grade a lot, and as there are unlimited attempts, it is therefore not hard to do so. The exam is a bit harder than the homework, you will have to really understand the content thoroughly to get good scores.

- Examination duration: final exam 3 hrs
- Percentage of coursework, examination, etc.:
   25% by homework
   75% by final exam
- The grading is based on students’ performance in assessment
   tasks.

For normal semesters, the grading will be different.
reviews.comment_workload: Understanding the concepts and practicing will be one of the major workload. Doing the HW is also one of them. The workload is appropriate for a 3-credit course.

Most of the content is in HKDSE M2 Syllabus, so it could be a waste a time for those who want to learn new things but took M2. Yet it is pleasant for those who want a good grade.

1 Number and intervals, inequalities and absolutes, functions and graphs, composite functions, exponential functions.

reviews.comment_teaching:
His pronunciation have significant CHINESE ACCENT, with VERY POOR pronunciation that even with 120% concentration, you can hardly understand what is he speaking.
Also, he uses mostly the example in the textbook to teach which makes it boring as hell.
I struggled for a few weeks, and I decided to skip ALL of the lectures. It is COMPLETELY A WASTE OF TIME. Sleeping is much more worth than talking his lectures

TA's accent is also heavy but at least understandable, yet he mostly gives us a set of exercise for us to do in Tutorial and just go through the questions. While other TA go through the homework.
Not very useful so skipped all of them after few tutorials
reviews.comment_grading:
Absolute grading.
75% of the grade is from Exam while 25% is from Homework.
That means if you screw up your exam, you'll probably fail the course.
I got a B, with 77.41% totally.
reviews.comment_workload:
Light workload with a total of 8 homework, each with around 10-15 questions on Classviva.
And just a Final Exam with 2.5h, consist of 3 parts.

reviews.comment_content:
Differentiability, Continuity, Intermediate Value Theorem, Mean Value Theorem, 'one-to-one' functions, Sandwich(Squeeze) Theorem, Linear Approximation, Newton's Method, Extreme Points, Rolle's Theorem, L'Hopital Rule, Riemann Sum, Fundamental Theorem of Calculus

Sep 22: Slope and Derivative, Precise Definition of Limit. [pdf]
Sep 24: Limits of Function Values, Asymptotes and Limits at Infinity, Limit Laws. [pdf]
Sep 29: Limit Laws, Extended Real Number System, Squeeze Theorem. [pdf]
Oct 01: National Day (No Classes)
Oct 06: Continuity of Functions, Intermediate Value Theorem, Basics of Derivatives. [pdf]
Oct 08: Basic Formulas of Derivatives, Rules of Differentiation, Chain Rule. [pdf]
Oct 13: Typhoon Signal No. 8 (No Classes)
Oct 15: Derivatives of Trigonometric Functions, Derivatives of Inverse Functions, Implicit Differentiation. [pdf]
Oct 20: Rates of Change, Higher-Order Derivatives. [pdf]
Oct 22: Extreme Values of Functions, Mean Value Theorem, Derivatives and Graphs. [pdf]
Oct 27: Convexity/Concavity and 2nd Derivatives, Graph Sketching. [pdf] [Code 1] [Code 2]
Oct 29: Optimization Problems, Characterization of Convexity/Concavity, Properties of Convex Functions. [pdf]
Nov 03: Geometric View and Global Minimum of Convex Functions, Linear Approximation. [pdf]
Nov 05: L'Hôpital's Rule, Convex Optimization. [pdf]
Nov 10: Newton's Method: Algorithm, Convergence Analysis and Application in Convex Optimization. [pdf] [Code]
Nov 12: Antiderivatives/Indefinite Integral, The Substitution Rule, Integration by Parts. [pdf]
Nov 17: Initial Value Problems, Area under Curve, Riemann Sums and Definite Integrals. [pdf]
Nov 19: More Examples of Definite Integrals, Fundamental Theorem of Calculus. [pdf]
Nov 24: The Proof of Fundamental Theorem of Calculus, Integrability, Taylor Series. [pdf]
Nov 26: Fundamental Theorem of Calculus (v2), Net Change, Substitution Rule and Symmetry in Definite Integrals. [pdf]
Dec 01: Course Review. [pdf]
Dec 03: Problems in Past Sample Papers. [Past Midterm Exam, Solution, Details of MC] [Past Final Exam, Solution]
Dec 09: Trail Exam. [Solutions]

reviews.comment_teaching: No comment. You can choose self-study if you take m2 in high school, but they're some new content that m2 doesn't cover.
reviews.comment_grading:
Assessment
15% by online homework
35% by the midterm exam
50% by the final exam

If you get full marks in webwork, and maybe the mean in two exams (~55-60%), by the scale:

reviews.comment_workload: Just webwork, and do the past paper before you take the midterm and final

reviews.author: JerGor
reviews.comment_content:
Just some fundamental calculus things
If you took M2 before you should know most of the content
There are just a few new things
(e.g. L’Hôpital’s rule, fundamental theorem of calculus)
If you took M1, well then... I guess it will be a bit tough? Good Luck

Content:
- intervals inequalities
- functions
- limit
- continuity
- differentiation
- L’Hôpital’s rule
- linear approximation
- newton's method
- rates
- graphing optimization
- indefinite integrals
- definite integrals
- Riemann sum
- fundamental theorem of calculus

In this course, techniques like integration by part,
trigonometric substitution won't even be taught
I think they will teach in MATH1014
reviews.comment_teaching:
He is nice and quite funny
He writes things on papers during lectures as his own notes
and he will scan and upload them back on Canvas
He will also upload other extra notes

He teaches things quite in detail
I think he spent a bit too much time on the early content
but I guess the pace is suitable for students
who are not very familiar with calculus
especially the M1 students, M2 students might feel boring
Overall I think he is a pretty good lecturer
reviews.comment_grading:
- Assignment: 25%
- Final: 75%
( No midterm )
( I think it used to have a midterm exam )

It is using absolute grading
The final exam is separated into 3 parts
which are just Multiple Choice Questions
( It used to have Long Questions )
each with around 8-10 questions

I got 2 mc wrong and full marks in HW and I only got an A
I guess you have to get 0-1 question wrong to get an A+
reviews.comment_workload:
There are only 8 Homework
and you can do as many time as you want in order to get full marks

They are on Classviva instead of Canvas
so make sure you don't miss any of them
especially you can get full marks easily

reviews.author: JustinYIP

Calculus.

Continuity, Differentiability, Intermediate Value Theorem, Mean Value Theorem, 'one-to-one' function, Solving problems with absolute functions, Sandwich(Squeeze) Theorem, Linear Approximation, Newton's Method, Critical Point, Rolle's Theorem, L'Hopital Rule, Reimann Sum, Fundamental Theorem of Calculus.
reviews.comment_teaching: LAM's teaching was said to be very detailed and funny, but I didn't attend even an entire class. Self-study plays a most important in studying this course well.

A

small

reviews.author: Serena17172
reviews.comment_content:
Generally speaking, the content is really the basic and
fundamental knowledge of university mathematics.There will be some textbook and lecture notes on Classiva for you to refer to.For me, it is very useful to consider these lecture notes as a tool for preview: after a quick scan, if I found I already know the
general logic and some examples of this chapter, then that will be perfect; if not, I will go through some concepts and detailed
-examples to have a overview of this chapter. Because of the style of the teaching part, it is indeed important.
reviews.comment_teaching:
For the teaching part, during the online teaching mode, all you can see is the screen-sharing of a draft paper(and the face of the professor), and the professor will demonstrate the process of
certain examples from lecture notes on Classiva. It could be really boring and useless if you just staring at the screen, most of the times you end up feeling sleepy. However, if you take some draft paper and calculate on your own with the professor or ahead of the professor, it would be much better.
reviews.comment_grading: There is no midterm, for the homework part, there is no limit in terms of submission, you can get full score if you want. Final term and practice before final term really matters.
reviews.comment_workload: Weekly quiz after class, the workload is generally 1 to 2 hours aweek if your do preview and review regularly. the workload will have a slight increase from beginning to final.

reviews.author: Arnoldcwn
reviews.comment_content: The content is interesting for me. It will be fun for those who are interested in mathematics.
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor has poor pronunciation in English. It makes it really hard to catch up on the topic discussing.
reviews.comment_grading: It depends a lot on final exam which is not a easy. However, you can get a good grade on homework part easily since there are unlimited attempts on assignments.
reviews.comment_workload: There are not much homework to be done. There are only one assignment every one or two weeks with some mathematical questions which is taught that week or the week before.

reviews.author: 御坂18520

reviews.comment_grading:
Absolute grading system is the fairest way to give students their grade. You should always try have to avoid any mistake during the exam and you will finally get an A+
75%final+25%assignment
Hope other courses can apply the absolute grading system as well.
reviews.comment_workload:
Not much workload, 8 assignments with multi-submit chances.
If you make mistake in your assignment just do them again then you will gain full mark on assignment.

reviews.author: vx
reviews.comment_content:
It is an introductory course in one-variable calculus.

Week 1
Number and intervals, inequalities and absolutes, functions and graphs, composite
functions, exponential functions.
Week 2
Trigonometric functions, inverse functions, logarithmic functions, inverse
trigonometric functions.
Week 3
Tangent and velocity, the limit of a function, limit laws.
Week 4
Continuity, limits at infinity and horizontal asymptotes, derivatives and rates of
change.
Week 5
Basic derivatives, product and quotient rules, derivatives of trigonometric functions.
Week 6
Chain rule, implicit differentiation, derivatives of inverse trigonometric functions and
logarithmic functions.
Week 7
Rates of change problems, related rates.
Week 8
Linear approximations and differentials, maximum and minimum values.
Week 9
Mean Value Theorem, derivatives and graphs, L’Hôpital’s rule.
Week 10
Curve sketching, optimization problems, Newton’s Method.
Week 11
Antiderivatives, areas and distances.
Week 12
Definite integrals, the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus.
Week 13
Applications of integrals, the substitution rule
reviews.comment_teaching:
The teaching is good. Prof. LI is really patient and willing to answer students' questions.

He even discussed some extra exercises in the class which really help me a lot in preparing for the final exam.

The TA is super nice, he explains the solutions step-by-step so it is easy to follow. The tutorial materials are useful.
reviews.comment_grading:
25% by homework
75% by final exam

There are unlimited attempts for homework. The marks for homework are based on the attempt with the highest score so basically people will get full marks for homework.

Due to covid-19, the final exam was conducted online with only MC questions.
reviews.comment_workload:
There are 8 assignments in total.
The workload is acceptable.

As I've never learnt much calculus before, it took me hours (sometimes a few days) to complete the homework. Do email the prof or TA when you face difficulties in doing the homework.

reviews.author: Hi_everyone
reviews.title: Normal content and normal grading
reviews.comment_content:
Simple calculus stuff:
limits, differentiation, graph sketch, maximization, integration.

The content is nothing special, but boring, as most of the content is covered in the DSE M2 syllabus.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The teaching is quite good.

Professor Li is very patient in answering questions, even though the questions asked are really stupid, he will spend time in lessons to answer them one by one.

However, he did spend a lot of time to show the justification of some laws and theorems, such as the fundamental theory of calculus, limits etc. , while justification does not really help the final exam.
reviews.comment_grading:
25% Homework
75% final exam

so actually the grade depends solely on the final exam.

doing past papers can really help.
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is fair.

8 assignments in total, each of them about 15 to 20 questions, take several hours to finish one.

reviews.author: Daniel's
reviews.title: No calculator for finals
reviews.comment_content:
New things for M1 students
Basic function (continuous, vertical & horizontal asymptote, simple invert function)

Trigonometric functions
[not in detail, most questions in exam are not difficult in the trigon part but the concepts of dy/dx or integration so m1 students don't need to be so worried for this part]

Limit (L'hopital rule)

Differentiation (squeeze theorem)

Integration ( Riemann's sums, Foundemental theory of calculus)
reviews.comment_teaching:
Yang Hui is willing to tech but his accent is difficult to understand
you need to pay full attention to understand what he is saying
and his notes is not very organized I often get lost while reading the notes he gave us

I would recommend reading the notes and Youtube the unknown stuff. it is much more effective and a easier way to understand everything

As for the tutors they also teaches fast, if you don't have a good foundation you will find it difficult to follow as they skip way to much steps while teaching us. they can differentiate and simplify a complicated function in one step without explanation.
reviews.comment_grading:
Homework 25%
Final 75%
Open book (though no digital notes, no surfing the web, no calculators allowed) only notes in paper are allowed
No calculator allowed !! though most questions in differentiation don't even have numbers or need calculator, but for limit and the  simple calculations, I still need a calculator.
reviews.comment_workload:
8 homework in total which contributes to 25% of final grade
unlimited attempt so better get full marks for every homework or else you would need to get a high mark in final
The homework are hard for me usually i would need to spend days to finish it.
No attendance for both lectures and tutors

reviews.author: anson1120
reviews.comment_content: Mainly Calculus, very hard if you do not pay effort. Really need to learn from other extra materials like textbook recommended or online videos. Otherwise bad grade or fail.

Not really good English but still manage to listen and understand. Nice professor willing to solve students questions.

TAs English are even worse. Cannot understand!
reviews.comment_grading: Absolute grading, people who are good at math will think it is reasonable grading, if you are bad at math, bad grade.

you have to do extra exercises in order to have a good grade.

reviews.author: Asagami Fujino
reviews.comment_content:
Just basic calculus things, though it goes deeper than calculus in JEE, most of them are high school stuff.
Limits, derivatives application, some integral, etc.
The coursebook is actually not that good. I would recommend "Calculus" written by Gilbert Strang, "The Calculus Lifesaver" and the "Thomas Calculus".
reviews.comment_teaching:
Her accent is not unbearable, but the teaching is quite bad. She basically reading the slides.
If you really want to learn something, taking tutorials should be enough. The TA actually teaches quite well, and she explains things quite clearly.
Besides, Highlights of Calculus (by Gilbert Strang from MIT) is probably a better choice if you regret skipping classes. (And his course is awesome!!!) Calculus videos by 3Blue1Brown is also a good source. (You can get a more intuitive view into what calculus really is)
You can also buy yourself a "The Calculus Lifesaver" or "Thomas Calculus", reading these two books and doing the exercises should be enough. (Unfortunately, the first book doesn't have exercises attached, at least for the Chinese translation.)
reviews.comment_grading:
Homework: 25%
Final exam: 75%

Final is all mc questions and I got 2 wrong.
Homework is near full.
Got A.
I think making 1 or less mistake can get you an A+, assuming your hw is full (which you should probably be)
reviews.comment_workload:
Not much homework and they're quite easy. For most homework, you can finish them easily in around 4 hours (for those with fewer questions, it's less than 3 hours)
But maybe you can find more exercises for yourself.

reviews.author: yjsm0120
reviews.title: Single Variable Calculus
reviews.comment_content:
Main topics are:
- Finding derivatives by first principles
- Limits
- Finding asymptotes
(Mid-term)
- Continuity
- Implicit differentiation
(Final)


Not many new concepts introduced at the end of the semester that have not been addressed in 1012 lectures. If you have studied MATH1012 hard enough, you should be able to handle the process quite easily.
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor analyzes the problem carefully and clearly.And PPT is also comprehensive, so it is easy to understand the contents. However, I recommend you to read the textbook and study on your own rather than watching the professor's lecture.
reviews.comment_grading:
Scoring isn't bad. There were 13 MCs on the test, and each question has an appropriate time allocated. However, it is true that if you don't know how to solve a problem as soon as you see it, you won't be able to solve it during the exam period.

I got 0.6 SD for midterms, 1.0 for final exams, and perfect for web work.

I got B

Which is above my expectation.
reviews.comment_workload:
It's quite heavy, you have to complete HW in class every week after week.
Classviva's input system is always problematic. Even the answer to most of the questions is quite complex. So you always have a problem with doing HW.

However, if you are looking for more than B range on this course, I recommend you to repeat classviva.

reviews.comment_teaching: 基本上成個課程教學都冇乜用，因為佢都幾係會將已經有嘅內容重新抄一次畀你然後話同你解釋返點樣推論過程單全部佢都唔會再有任何應用，建議你可以上網自己搵片會快啲同埋更加有用
reviews.comment_grading:
如果你遇錯一個助教咁樣嘅話，好多時候你做嘅練習只會係白費氣力，因為同考試嘅內容可以有超過九成都唔同，最好就係問人搵其他年份嘅資料同埋練習，又或者搵下同你讀同一個課程但其他助教練習。
成績算係一般般
reviews.comment_workload: 基本上得網上功課，所以其實冇乜嘢工作。但如果你係想要好成績麻煩請你化多啲心機，係搵練習做方面。唔好以為佢出嘅題型會一樣

reviews.author: FishCHAN
reviews.comment_content:
The material provided is not enough for you to get through the final and mid term exam.
The homework required is much more easier than the questions that you will see in the exam.
Even for me, a student who have studied M2 in Secondary school, get a poor grade as a result (though i have strived for it and have done a lot of revision).
So, for those who need to take this course, wish you good luck ;)
reviews.comment_teaching:
The material provided by different professors are different.
For my case, the notes provided by the professor are quite detailed.
reviews.comment_grading: I get a poor grade, maybe i have not studied that much before my final exam because i get sick :( As a result, the result of my final exam is really bad, which makes my grade poorer (actually i perform quite fair in my mid-term examination, but if you fail in your final exam, i can only tell that your grade will be poor).
reviews.comment_workload:
You only need to complete the assignment via classviva only, the workload is okay because the homework given by the professor is just a few questions (maybe at most, 20 questions)
You are recommended to complete ASAP, as the homework is not that difficult.
The tutorial is optional, so you can choose to go or not.

reviews.author: Minnie Tong
reviews.title: NO MORE MATH COURSE IN UST PLEASE:)
reviews.comment_content: Basic M2 stuff. It will be great if you have studied M2 in DSE. M1 guys will die as you know nothing about M2 and you can hardly survive with those M2 people.
reviews.comment_teaching: She got after-lecture notes. You can study them before the midterm and final. They are quite useful tbh. You can understand her English because her English is okay alright.
reviews.comment_grading: Fking absolute grading. As I have mentioned above, M1 people will die (like me lolll). NO calculator is allowed during midterm and final :)
reviews.comment_workload: Every week has regular online homework to complete. The workload is huge because you need to get full marks to get 15% of the course.

reviews.author: SweetCandy
reviews.comment_content:
Similar to High School Mathematics, but with higher and more in-depth analytical questions.

Numbers, Inequalities, and Absolute Values
Function
Limit and Continuity
The derivative of a Function & Formulas of Differentiation
More Exercises for Sandwich Theorem and Evaluation of Derivatives
Applications of Differentiation: Rate of Change
Linear Approximation, Newton’s Method, Extreme Values
Mean Value Theorem, Shape of Graph and L’hopital’s Rule
Technique for Solving Inequality & Curve Sketching
Antiderivatives, Reimann Sum and Fundamental Theorem of Calculus
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor's teaching is easy to understand and always come prepared before the classes. Just make sure to seat in the front and in the middle of the class so that you can see all the professor's writing. (He usually used all the three whiteboards in the class)
reviews.comment_grading:
15% Web Homework
35% Midterm Exam
50% Final Exam
No attendance

You can get full score in the web homework since it is unlimited attempts until the deadline.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is normal. You just have to do the web homework weekly and practice for the exams using the past papers.

reviews.author: Random ppl
reviews.comment_content: Most of them are Dse M2 stuff. The others are most likely build upon the M2 stuff. So basically if you are a DSE-M1 student, good luck cuz it's gonna be hard.
reviews.comment_teaching: Just be honest with you. I skipped all math class after a week or two cuz I can't understand due to his strong mainland accent. It is very difficult to learn anything from his lesson. The only good thing of him is that he sent the weekly schedule out so even if you don't attend class, you know where he is right now.
reviews.comment_grading: Idk cuz I don't attend class and don't understand the topics at all so what I got is pretty decent, except for the trash online exam system. I can't load a few pictures during the exam and I got no help from the tutors (all they said is to use another browser which I tried) which I was forced to give up some questions. Thank god they are MCs.
reviews.comment_workload: The only HW is to complete Classviva regularly, normally after each chapter. Just be mindful that Classviva crash down occasionally and it might be disastrous if it didn't save your answers automatically.

Most people skip lessons.
If you are studying m1 in dse, go and revise some m2 materials before attending lectures. Questions in m2 textbook can help you understanding the concept. Or go and reg LAM, Tsz Kin lessons instead.

Willing to answer students inquiries.
Strong Chinese accent and you might need to take a few lessons to adapt to it.
reviews.comment_grading:
Midterm Final below mean.
HW full marks.
B-

No quiz.
Classviva (assignments) are easy to get full marks and it provides much time for you to complete it. Dont do it in the last minute.

Nothing speical. some differentiation and basic calculus

the whole thing is very conceptual.

reviews.author: Michael Jhon
reviews.title: basic calculus
reviews.comment_content:
Basic calculus. I think everybody has done this in their high school.
1. function
2. limit and curve sketching
3. differentiations and its applications
4. riemann sum and definite integrals
reviews.comment_teaching:
Her teaching was good, but she has an accent that sometimes make an unclear pronunciation  

Her notes was very neat and good. If you are lazy to write a note than take her class
reviews.comment_grading:
Absolute grading i think. so mean and sd does not affect ur grade.
50% final
35% midterm
15% hw
reviews.comment_workload: Every 1 to 3 weeks there will be 1-2 hw which counts toward ur final grade but you can try as much as possible until you get 100.

reviews.author: Wing1
reviews.comment_content: The course is mainly about calculus, some of them might be taught in high school. The course teaches limits, integral and other things. The course is related to the course Math 1014.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The teaching of both lecturer and TA is good!
The tutor explains every thing well and his presentation is clear and easy to understand. His notes are good and have different examples. His teaching speed is also appropriate. He is willing to answer questions by the students and explain them clearly with patience. He tries to make his lessons interesting.
The TA teaches well also. Her notes are good and she teaches clearly with appropriate examples so that we can understand easily.
reviews.comment_grading:
There is homework, midterm exam and final exam count towards the grade. Most people get full mark for homework.
The homework counts 15%, midterm counts 35% and final exam counts 50%.
The grade is absolute grading.
There are multiple choice questions and short questions in midterm exam. As the final exam changes to online mode, all questions are multiple choice questions.
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is appropriate.
There are assignments(homework), midterm exam and final exam.
There is one assignment each 2 to 3 weeks and there is much time to finish them. The content of assignments is appropriate. Most people get full mark for all assignments.
The lectures and tutorials are not compulsory.

reviews.author: YIN.
reviews.title: Not a Difficult Course Even If You Study M1
reviews.comment_content:
Covers some topics in HKDSE (basic derivatives) as well as some new topics (L’Hôpital’s rule, Mean value theorem, Intermediate value theorem, Fundamental theorem of calculus...).

As a M1 student in DSE, it is not hard to catch up with the course even I had not learnt trigonometry differentiation and graph sketching, which was taught in M2.

Get yourself familiar with the theorems as they are often used in exam for proofing.
reviews.comment_teaching:
YANG Hui writes everything in the textbook on the whiteboard and read them aloud with his "excellent" English. I only attended his first two lectures and skipped the rest of them. I highly recommend LAM, Tsz Kin's lecture as he explain things way better and he has excellent notes.
Phyllis LIANG's tutorial is also great. Her notes and exercises are well prepared.
reviews.comment_grading:
Homework × 8 - 15%
Midterm - 35%
Final - 50%

Homework 100%
Midterm 82%
Final 85%
Overall 86.2
Grade A-
reviews.comment_workload:
1.5 hr × 2 lectures + 1 hr tutorial
8 homework in total, have around 1 month to complete after it is open. It usually take 1 - 2 hr to complete each homework.

但明白概念好緊要
唔係轉下D問法就唔識做架啦

又貼近exam format
reviews.comment_grading:

<40 F

50-70 C range

85-100 A range

Midterm Exam (F2F, Closed Book): 77/100 (35%)
Final Exam (Online, Open HARDCOPY Book and Notes): 75/100 (50%)
Overall 79.45/100 -> B+
我係L02, overall mean係~69分

Final exam全部MC 5分一題MC

所以容錯率唔高 要小心D做

因為final exam轉做全部MC題
所以轉左做curve grade
調低左cut off :)
應該係最好grade既一年
reviews.comment_workload:
一般般啦
每1-2星期就有一份Classviva Online Exercise要做
可以做無限次 做到滿分為止

最緊要明D approach點做

reviews.author: DrainGang
reviews.title: Get a khan academy account
reviews.comment_content:
limits, differentiation and integration (only up to substitution)

Mostly M2 stuff, so if you are a M1 student (like me), prepare to suffer. Get a khan academy account and just watch the videos on there to learn, its a lot easier to understand the videos and also its way more efficient than wasting 2 hours in your lectures when you can be doing something else. (Even if its just sleeping in your bed.)
reviews.comment_teaching:
Lecturer: barely acceptable, heavy accent, poor English, notes are NOT very good, lessons are a bit boring with pacing too slow. Would give him a B- for effort as I can at least see him trying to spice things up with jokes and stuff (even if they are not funny...)

He also only taught the lesson content so good luck on how to approach questions in your homework or exams.

TA: Awful, decent English but seems to be in quite the hurry every single tutorial as the tutorials always end 10-20 MINUTES before they should. Would answer some questions when asked. If this guy is your TA, just skip the tutorials.
reviews.comment_grading:
Midterm (35%), webwork (15%), Finals (50%)

Webwork: while time-consuming, the 15% it gives to the grade is almost free as you have unlimited amounts of retries to finish them, and you SHOULD finish them as everyone else probably does, if you don't, you will put yourself in a major disadvantage. I got all 15%.

Midterm: from the beginning all the way to newton's method, included both MCs and long questions, quite difficult. I got around mean.

Finals: conducted online with only MCs, includes ALL materials taught, notes are allowed, also quite difficult. I got around mean also.

Grading: Absolute grading unless they decide to change it to a curve, either way the grading WILL be very poor, getting mean will net you a C or maybe a C+? (feel like that's very unlikely.)
reviews.comment_workload: Medium to high, the webwork takes a while (3-4 hours per webwork, 15 in total) and do some past papers or questions before exams, quite a lot of effort if you are not the most talented at mathematics. Again, good luck if you took M1 in secondary school.

reviews.author: momochi
reviews.comment_content: Very difficult. Mostly M2 content, along with some new stuff.
reviews.comment_teaching: His accent is absolutely terrible. Couldn't understand his English at all. I gave up attending classes after 2 lectures and ended up learning on my own. Other than the assignments, there is only one sample paper before exams. It would be much better if there are more opportunities for us to practice.
reviews.comment_grading:
Absolute grading
Even if you are around the mean, you will still get C range.
Having full mark in assignments really helps.
reviews.comment_workload: Workload is fine. Although webwork are quite hard, you can try as many times as you want. I actually want more practice questions before exams.

Most of the topics are m2 stuffs, about 60% m2 stuffs.
but some new concepts are included, like interval, linear approximations...
reviews.comment_teaching: The teaching is quite good as she explained concepts very clearly, and the notes she provided are well-organized.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading include 3 parts:
First of all, online homework (about 13) that you can do over and over again.
The trial with highest mark will be counted.
The second part is the mid-term exam is quite challenging, but interesting as well.
The third part is final exam, which is quite challenging,
but remember, the most important thing is to remember all the concepts in orgranized way, if u can do so, u can get at least 80 %  in exams.
(NO NEED ATTENDENCE)
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is definitely not high, only about 13 hw.

Continuity, Differentiability, Intermediate Value Theorem, Mean Value Theorem, 'one-to-one' function, Solving problems with absolute functions, Sandwich(Squeeze) Theorem, Linear Approximation, Newton's Method, Critical Point, Rolle's Theorem, L'Hopital Rule, Reimann Sum, Fundamental Theorem of Calculus

please make sure don't be confident even if you studied M2, it is very difficult to score high mark in this course.

reviews.author: Andrewwww
reviews.title: Ok course
reviews.comment_content:
Calculus. Half DSE-M2 stuff, half new things. Good luck if you are M1.
Here's a list(not complete) of non-M2 stuffs in this course:
Continuity, Differentiability, Intermediate Value Theorem, Mean Value Theorem, 'one-to-one' function, Solving problems with absolute functions, Sandwich(Squeeze) Theorem, Linear Approximation, Newton's Method, Critical Point, Rolle's Theorem, L'Hopital Rule, Reimann Sum, Fundamental Theorem of Calculus(A little more things than DSE M2)
reviews.comment_teaching: Bored not very interesting
reviews.comment_grading:
Semi-absolute grading. Much fairer than previous semesters.
15% WebWork 35% Mid-term 50% Final
Total score
85-100%-->A range
70-85%-->B range
50-70%-->C range
40-50%-->D
0-40%-->Fail
reviews.comment_workload:
Homework: Basically 1 WebWork(Online homework) per week, each consists of 10-18 questions. Apart from the first one you will need 2-4 hours to finish one, not very heavy workload. You can attempt questions infinitely many times , so try your best to get full marks in them!
No attendance required for any lecture and tutorials
Exam: Do your best in the relatively simple mid-term to secure a better grade earlier. All contents will appear in final exam, so don't forget to practice on evaluating limits for the final. I focused too much on integration and didn't do a single question of limits before the final, so I lose at least 9 marks on some relatively simple limit MCs, sigh~~

reviews.author: Vickkkyy
reviews.comment_content:
Basic calculus content

Prerequisite: Level 3 or above in HKDSE Mathematics Extended Module M1/M2.

Exclusion: AL Pure Mathematics, AL Applied Mathematics; Math1003, Math1012, Math1014, Math1018, Math1020, Math1023, Math1024.

Brief Information/synopsis:

This is an introductory course in one-variable calculus. Topics include functions and graphs, limits of functions and continuity, derivatives and their applications, basic indefinite and definite integrals.



Intended Learning Outcomes:

1
Develop basic computational skills in calculus.
2
Express quantitative relationships using the language of functions.
3
Apply the concepts and methods of calculus in modeling and problem-solving.

reviews.author: 871djclqnc

reviews.comment_content:
Some of the contents are from DSE M2 syllabus.
Week one: Sep 03, 05, 07:
Functions, their representations. (1.1)
Some basic functions. (1.2)
Exponential functions, inverse functions, logarithms (1.4, 1.5)
New functions from old functions (composition) (1.3)

Week two: Sep 10, 12, 14:
Trigonometric functions. (appendix D)
Inverse trigonometric functions (appendix D)
Tangent and velocity. (2.1)

Week three: Sep 17, 19, 21:
Definition of limit (2.2)
Basic rules for limit calculations. (2.3)
Continuity. (2.5)

Week four: Sep 24, 26, 28:
Limit at infinity, and horizontal asymptotes. (2.6)
Derivatives and rates of change. (2.7)
Basic Derivatives. (2.8, 3.1)

Week five: Oct 03, 05
Differentiation rules, product, quotient. (3.2)
Derivatives of trigonometic functions. (3.3)
Chain rule. (3.4)

Week six: Oct 08, 10, 12:
Implicit differentiation. (3.5)
Derivatives of logarithmic functions, and inverse trignometric functions. (3.6)

Week seven: Oct 15, 19;
Rate change problems, and exponential growth. (3.7, 3.8)
Related Rates. (3.9)

Week eight: Oct 22, 24, 26:
Linear approximations, and differentials. (3.10)
Newton's method. (4.8)
Applications, maxima, minima. (4.1)



Midterm Exam: Oct 28 (Sunday Morning 10:15-11:45)



Week nine: Oct 29, 31, Nov 02:
Mean value theorem. (4.2)
Derivatives and the shape of a graph. (4.3)
L'Hopital's rule. (4.4)

Week ten: Nov 05, 07, 09:
Curve sketching. (4.5, 4.6)
Optimization problems. (4.7)

Week eleven: Nov 12, 14, 16:
Anti-derivatives. (4.9)
Areas and distances. (5.1)

Week twelve: Nov 19, 21, 23:
Definite integrals. (5.2)
The Fundamental Theorem of Calculus. (5.3)

Week thirteen: Nov 26, 28, 30:
Indefinite integrals and net change. (5.4)
Substitution. (5.5)

reviews.author: orxygen
reviews.title: math1013
reviews.comment_content:
As a local student, I studied M2 before.
The content is quite similar to what i have learnt before , this course is a advanced and comprehensive version of M2 calculus in secondary school so i found it quite easy to pick up. For those who have took M1 in the secondary school should pay much attention to the course content especially for the trigonometry and integration (substitution and by part). Here is the content in detail.

1.1 Review of functions,
1.2 Representing functions,
1.3 Inverse, exponential and logarithmic functions
1.4 Trigonometric functions and their inverses,

2.1 The idea of limits,
2.2 Definitions of limits
2.3 Techniques for computing limits,
2.4 Infinite limits,
2.5 Limits at infinity,
2.6 Continuity

3.1 Introducing the derivatives,
3.2 Rules of differentiation
3.2 Rules of differentiation,
3.3 The product and quotient rules,
3.4 Derivatives of trigonometric functions,
3.5 Derivatives as rates of change,
3.6 The chain rule
3.7 Implicit differentiation,
3.8 Derivatives of logarithmic and exponential functions,
3.9 Derivatives of inverse trigonometric functions
3.10 Related rates,

4.1 Maxima and minima
4.2 What derivatives tell us,
4.3 Graphing functions,
4.4 Optimization problems
4.5 Linear approximation and differentials,
4.6 Mean value theorem,
4.7 L'Hopital's rule
4.8 Newton's method (*),
4.9 Antiderivatives

5.1 Approximating areas under curves,
5.2 Definite integrals
5.3 Fundamental theorem of calculus,
5.4 Working with integrals
5.5 Substitution rule

reviews.author: diuhitnds
reviews.title: Fk you always teaches wrong things
reviews.comment_content:
CONTENT

Calculus. Most of them are part of the  DSE-M2 syllabus. As this is a foundation course, the content of it is not challenging at all, so don't be too afraid if you are M1 in high school.
Here's a list of new things learnt in this course:
Continuity, Differentiability, Intermediate Value Theorem, Mean Value Theorem, 'one-to-one' function, Solving problems with absolute functions, Sandwich(Squeeze) Theorem, Linear Approximation, Newton's Method, Critical Point, Rolle's Theorem, L'Hopital Rule, Reimann Sum, Fundamental Theorem of Calculus, integration and differentiation of inverse trigonometric functions.
reviews.comment_teaching:
TEACHING

Prof Chiang's English is clear, and he is willing to answer student's questions. However, his writes on the whiteboard in a less organised way, so it's not easy to follow. The teaching pace is slow, and he put too much time on explaining the fundamental knowledge that both M1 and M2 and even DSE Maths core should have covered, especially functions... He should have put more explanation on new topics such as L'Hopital Rule and more...

I didn't attend any tutorials.
reviews.comment_grading:
GRADING

Semi-absolute grading. Much fairer than previous semesters.
15% WebWork 35% Mid-term 50% Final
Total score
85-100%-->A range
70-85%-->B range
50-70%-->C range
40-50%-->D
0-40%-->Fail
Me:
WebWork Full mark
Mid-term 63/100 (Mean: 57)
Final 74/100 (Mean:  47)
Total 70/100  -->B
quite weird as the mean is exceptionally low for my year so i guess that's why my grades is slightly better than the absolute grading system.
reviews.comment_workload:
WORKLOAD

Homework: Basically 1 WebWork(Online homework) every two weeks, each consists at most 18 questions. WebWorks before the mid term should be quite easy and can be completed in an hour. But those after the mid term are quite challenging so please arrange enough tine for it, don't be a deadline fighter like me. You can attempt rhe questions infinite times ,therefore, try to get full marks in them.
No attendance required for any lecture and tutorials
Exam: Do your best in the relatively simple mid-term to secure a better grade. All contents will appear in final exam, so don't forget to practice on early topics for the final.

reviews.comment_teaching:
林子健教得一般,正常水平
不過聽講其他教得仲差過佢

reviews.comment_grading: 一般la,係absolute grading,正常唔會太差,跟個分比grade
reviews.comment_workload: 正常數course workload,要做下webwork, lecture同tutor冇attendence 成sem唔出現都冇問題

reviews.author: fl0ra
reviews.title: Be careful if you want a good grade
reviews.comment_content:
Basically the content is high school knowledge, especially the content before midterm, so you may feel bored at the beginning. However, the content becomes much more difficult after the midterm. Take care.
Before midterm (partially)
Exponential functions, inverse functions, logarithms, trigonometric functions, definition of limit, limit at infinity and horizontal asymptotes, derivatives, related rates, Newton's method
After midterm (partially)
L'Hopital's rule, curve sketching, anti-derivatives, definite integrals, indefinite integrals, the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus.
reviews.comment_teaching:
MOY Allen is a patient professor with fluent English and neat handwriting. His lecture notes are clear and easy to understand. The pace is relatively slow, so sometimes I almost fell asleep and sadly miss out some important points. He is willing to answer students questions and write down every step for students to make sure they fully understand.
To be honest, tutorial is more helpful in terms of getting a good grade.
reviews.comment_grading:
I believe this course is absolute grade, which means you probably need 95/100 to get an A+. Therefore, in order to get a good grade, you need to be extremely careful and pay special attention to the details.
midterm 35% final 50% homework 15%
Provisional grade scale:   F < 40% < D < 50% < C's < 70% < B's < 85% < A's ( I believe A+>95%)
mine
midterm:93/100
final:87/100
homework: 15%/15%
turn out to be an A
reviews.comment_workload: You don't have to memorize lots of things and the questions on Webwork are quite easy and short for most students. My suggestion is that if you want to get a good grade, you should do some extra exercise and finish the tutorial worksheets which are similar to the questions in the exams.

reviews.author: JastinYu
reviews.comment_content:
Learning basic knowledge from high school,if you have taken M2 in HKDSE,it will not so hard for you to study this course.
This course also included some advanced knowledge especially differentiations.
Remember to attend every tutorial,especially Walter Chan,he is a good TA.Tutorial can save your life
reviews.comment_teaching: Have little accent,you may talk to professor after lesson by using putonghua.
reviews.comment_grading:
Final and mid-term are harder than homework of course
Very easy to get full marks from all online homework.
reviews.comment_workload: There is only one online homework for each week.

reviews.author: amyriad
reviews.title: Don't make any mistake or you will lose a subgrade
reviews.comment_content:
M2 DSE stuffs mainly in first half
Exponential functions, inverse functions, logarithms
Trigonometric functions, Inverse trigonometric functions
Tangent and velocity
Limit, Continuity
Limit at infinity, asymptotes
Derivatives, Differentiation (Implicit and Explicit)
Exponential growth ***IMPORTANT***
Linear approximations
Newton's method
Maxima, Minima
Mean value theorem
Shape of a graph, Curve sketching, Optimization
L'Hopital's rule
Anti-derivatives, Definite integrals, Reimann Sum
Substitution, Indefinite integrals
Areas and distances
reviews.comment_teaching: Tsz Kin may make some mistakes in teaching and pause until he finds them out so please remind him in case you know the problem in order not to end the lesson late. It is better to understand the concept of the course materials and don't just rely on the stated examples in class.
reviews.comment_grading:
Semi-absolute grading which is VERY FRAGILE with any of your careless mistakes in the paper.
Semi-absolute means the absolute grading for grade range but curve in sub-grades.
A+ boundaries is extremely high (probably the boundaries is somehow between 95 and 97.5, so no TOLERANCE)
Grading system: https://intranet.math.ust.hk/grading/student (Intranet so you have to use Pulse Secure / Virtual Barn (Now also requires Pulse Secure) outside the campus or Wi-Fi network or Computer Barn inside the Campus in order to access it)

Homework: 15% (Remember to get full for this part!!!)
Mid-term Exam: 35%
Final Exam: 50%
No calculator allowed.

**Score are rounded to 1 d.p.first, so 84.96, 85.03 is also 85**
A range = 85~100
B range = 70~85
C range = 50~70
D range = 40~50
F = 0~40


The English can be an killer as it may contains some data that are not useful or some information that you may overread. Tsz Kin and TA is not very tolerant to small mistakes in the steps even the method is completely correct and the answer is just flawed in one single step they would not give any marks starting from that line and deduct 10 marks from your exam and steal your expected grade off a subgrade. (i.e. if the constant is missing in the first step due to the overreading of the question, then you are unlucky. They may introduce the constant inflow rate and a variable leaking rate so if you forget to add the inflow rate, your whole answer will be sucked by a single constant offset and every steps will not be kindly treated by the markers). How is it supposed that the thing that killed you is the texts but not mathematics?

As the final exam contributes to 50% score, a 10% deduction in final equals 5% in overall score and probably a subgrade deduction.
reviews.comment_workload:
Webwork: useful for practice but not so useful for grades.
(https://webwork.math.ust.hk/webwork2/2018_FALL_MATH1013)

No reminder to deadline so it is better to finish the assignment as soon as possible.
INFINITE chances (theoretically), so you can guess the answer of Multiple-Choices and Multiple-Checkboxes questions.
Each homework lasts for a month and consists of about 13 questions. There are 9 homeworks, 120 questions in total (time may overlap with answer homework)
Some answers are very ugly in closed form so Ctrl+C and Ctrl+V are your friends if you insisted not to use approximated values (remember to copy also the outer bracket pair of the repeated part so you will not get wrong).

reviews.author: Hydrargyrum
reviews.title: Good grade and easy to learn
reviews.comment_content:
For mainland students, it is quite easy to understand the content. It only covers the former part of calculus and it only teaches basic concepts and simple computing.
It contains:
Numbers, Inequalities, and Absolute Values
Function
Limit and Continuity
The derivative of a Function & Formulas of Differentiation
More Exercises for Sandwich Theorem and Evaluation of Derivatives
Applications of Differentiation: Rate of Change
Linear Approximation, Newton’s Method, Extreme Values
Mean Value Theorem, Shape of Graph and L’h𝐨̂ptal’s Rule
Technique for Solving Inequality & Curve Sketching
Antiderivatives, Reimann Sum and Fundamental Theorem of Calculus
and the exam mainly tests your ability in derivative and antiderivatives.
reviews.comment_teaching: I think the professor prepare for the class with intention and the notes are full of knowledge. Tutorials will give you enough questions to practice so it is of no use to worry about the exercise.
reviews.comment_grading:
quite easy to get A range if you paid enough work on this course.
if you get >85%, you will have A range. If you have 95% you will get A+.
15% webwork
35% midterm
50% final
reviews.comment_workload: Not very heavy. The only thing you need to do is to finish your web work on time. and have exercises and past paper before midterm and final.

some contents are similar to M2
but the question is more in-depth than M2.

reviews.comment_grading:
mid-term 30%
Final 50%
Webwork 20%
reviews.comment_workload: 10 webworks and you only need to give the final answer, no step.  if you have any question about webwork, you could go to the math center to and they will teach you how to do the web work.

C+

reviews.author: ChrisCat
reviews.comment_content: The content is essentially the similar thing to M2 DSE, and the worse part is that even you know in M2, you can struggle in terms of understanding the question. I recommend plenty of self-studying since you have to learn maths by self-practice anyway.
reviews.comment_teaching: Let's be honest here, Professor Moy doesn't really teach here, he just says the concept and did it with very little elaboration. He might do a lot of demonstration there, especially in the WebWork problems, but again he doesn't elaborate much, which can be very confusing if you are not enthusiastic on going to the Math Center for solutions.
reviews.comment_grading:
Your grade is divided into the following pattern:
35% Mid Term
50% Final Exam
15% WebWork

I essentially perfected the WebWork, yet I performed quite substandard in both midterm and final, as I got the score below mean a little bit. In the end, I got C-.
I suggest you guys not to procrastinate when doing the WebWork, I know many of my classmates have a problem finishing their WebWork because they are simply too lazy! The homework can be easily completed once you grabbed the concept properly.
No need to worry about attendance, since I mentioned that it would not be included in your grade. I know a friend who almost constantly skipped the class, and he mostly does other things in class.
reviews.comment_workload:
Professor Moy doesn't give any extra assignments at all, all you need to do is to complete the WebWork.
If you want good grades in your exams though, again, self-study is the key. I suffer some not so satisfactory grades simply I didn't spend much time on study.

reviews.comment_teaching:
For the lecture session, he had a strong accent in speaking English, which made students difficult to understand what he said. Basically, he went through the PowerPoint slides from the textbook publisher. The PowerPoint slides were uploaded to Canvas after each lecture for reference.

For the tutorial session, colour-printed notes with explanations and past paper examples were given to students. She also gave us some time to go through the examples before explaining the answers. Students could also ask questions outside the classroom when the tutorial session ended.

reviews.comment_workload:
This course covered many topics taught in M2 and also several new topics which were difficult. Since I studied M1 in the past, there was a heavier workload for me comparing to other M2 students.

For the WeBWorK assignments, a new exercise was assigned about every week. Each exercise consisted of about 10 questions, some of which were challenging. However, since there were unlimited attempts and no time limits, it was not difficult to get full marks in these assignments. You could search online to find the solutions easily if you didn't understand the question. Just remember to mark down the homework deadlines on a calendar, since the due dates are quite irregular and it is easy to forget completing them before the deadline.

For the Midterm and Final exams, they consist of about 20 MC questions and several long questions. No calculators were allowed. It is recommended to finish the sample papers beforehand, which had a similar format comparing to the exam questions. Also, some WebWorK questions were similar to those in the exams, so understanding them also helps you to prepare for the exams.

reviews.author: IY
reviews.title: Poor grading and good luck for M1 students
reviews.comment_content:
University Calculus course (Part I).
Quite many DSE M2 Content so it is an advantage for M2 students. For M1 students, good luck to you. :)
• Numbers, inequalities and absolute values (Appendix A)
• Coordinate Geometry and Lines
• Basic functions and graphs, composite functions (1.1, 1.2, 1.3)
• Exponential functions (1.5)
• Trigonometric functions (Appendix D)
• Inverse functions, logarithmic functions and inverse trigonometric functions (1.6, Appendix D)
• Tangent and velocity (2.1)
• The limit of a function, limit laws (2.2, 2.3)
• Continuity (2.5)
• Limits at infinity and horizontal asymptotes (2.6)
• Derivatives and rates of change (2.7)
• Basic derivatives (2.8, 3.1)
• Product and quotient rules (3.2)
• Derivatives of trigonometic functions (3.3)
• Chain rule (3.4)
• Implicit differentiation, derivatives of inverse trigonometric functions and logarithmic functions (3.5, 3.6)
• Rates of change problems (3.7, 3.8)
• Related Rates. (3.9)
• Linear approximations and differentials (3.10)
• Newton's method (4.8)
• Maximum and minimum values (4.1)
• Mean Value Theorem (4.2)
• Derivatives and the shape of a graph (4.3)
• L'Hopital's rule (4.4)
• Curve sketching (4.5, 4.6)
• Optimization problems (4.7)
• Anti-derivatives (4.9)
• Areas and distances (5.1)
• Definite integrals (5.2)
• The Fundamental Theorem of Calculus (5.3)
• Indefinite integrals and net change (5.4)
• Substitution rule (5.5)
reviews.comment_teaching:
Dr. Lam is already regarded as one of the best lecturers for this course. (Because I have never attended other Math 1013 sessions so I don't know how "bad" other lecturers teach.)

Overall speaking, his teaching is clear if you pay attention in lectures. But quite boring for me (maybe just because I am not that interested in Math) and his handwriting is not clear. He also mentions a lot of proof and things that will not be tested in the exams. Good if you love math so much though.

However, I do have to say his TA (Phyllis LIANG) is very good. She explains how to do the questions clearly. Quite exam-oriented as well as she will discuss past exam questions with us during her tutorials. She is very nice and willing to answer questions as well. Also, she always points out the common mistakes made by students.
reviews.comment_grading:
Absolute Grading.
85% from uniform exams = 35% Midterm + 50% Final Exam
15% from online WeBWork homework
Grade scale:   F < 40% < D < 50% < C's < 70% < B's < 85% < A's

In other words, if the paper is easy, you can get a good grade.
However, if in your semester the paper is difficult, you will get a poor grade. like me :(
So what grade you will get largely depends on your luck.

Of course, if you are extremely good at Math, you can get a good grade anyway so just ignore.
reviews.comment_workload:
9 set of Homework on WebWork with unlimited attempts.
Remember to finish all before the deadline so that you get full mark for your homework part and prepare for your exam.

reviews.author: Timmy___
reviews.title: 學果陣可以掌握 考果陣非常難
reviews.comment_content: 教嘅topic其實唔多，中學M1/M2都有涉獵，主要喺differentiation同integration，不過會相對深入好多好多(會有Newton's method, mean value theorem, intermediate value theorem, etc 其他reviews都有提及，我就唔贅述啦)。雖然我中學喺讀M1，但喺相對讀M2嘅同學嚟講應該只喺少左trigonometry,curve sketching嘅部分，所以要追返應該都得嘅，不過當然要下苦功。
reviews.comment_teaching: 會教二十幾堂lectures，所以教學嘅進度都算循序漸進，唔會話學唔切，因為topic都唔算多。
reviews.comment_grading:
15% webwork
35% midterm
50% final
Webwork 做曬就滿分，但啲deadline有少少飄忽，所以記得mark低啲deadline。
Midterm 同 final 就真喺嚇親我，因為試題嘅難度喺比起lecture嘅examples, tutorial嘅題目同埋webwork難同埋刁鑽好多，所以mean 通常得50～60左右，可惜呢個course 喺計absolute grading (F < 40% < D < 50% < C's < 70% < B's < 85% < A's)，所以要靠自己。
reviews.comment_workload:
如果你掌握到嘅話，workload只有webwork。
否則，如果要喺Midterm,Final考得好，真喺要好熟好熟啲concepts，所以難免考之前做多啲數。

The professor is quite boring and you may not understand what he's talking about. He will upload his class notes and 'slides' on the intranet so please refer if you don't understand the homework. He basically talks about the homework solutions for half a lesson.

The TA is friendly but she teaches difficult stuff in tutorials that most likely won't be tested in the exam.
reviews.comment_grading:
Homework (WebWorK) 15%
Midterm 35%
Final 50%

Midterm: 12-13 MCQ + 4 LQ
Final: ~20 MCQ + ~4 LQ

Absolute Grading:
85%+ A Range
(85% < A- < ~90% < A < ~95% < A+)

<40% Fail

The class mean is not important because it is only your score that matters.
reviews.comment_workload: 10 Sets of WebWorK, each consists of around 10-15 questions, answers only and no steps required, unlimited attempts, as long as you find a friend with good maths, you will get carried and get all 15% for homework as you finish them all in time.

reviews.author: Never Social
reviews.title: Basic math course, too basic tbh.
reviews.comment_content:
Refer to other posts for topics included.

Math1013, for students with M1/M2 background you say? More like treating you as junior highschool students! Hell, a too long amount of time is used to explain even the simplest concepts that as M1/M2 students should already know/ more then capable of understanding in an instant.

"Online homework" is done over at Webwork. Should be easy enough, keep inputing different answers until correct then bingo bongo get the marko. Just remember to do them, the weekly deadlines aren't regular so keep in mind.

Good thing is, the mid-term/ exam tends to assess abstract concepts rather then your computational prowess (no calc allowed in final) so if you know the whole syllabus and attended all the tutorials (which i didn't), all g.

All and all ez course.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Boi this lecturer just bore me to death. His careless mistakes, his/ this course's slow place. He uploads his handwritten paper used in lectures online, though good luck figuring out what he wrote and which topic is being covered if you didn't attend the lecture. I didn't bother attending his lectures since wk 5 or so.

Tutorial wise, the first wk gave me a bad impression (worksheets too easy, explainations too long) so I didn't attend the rest of them, which proved to be a mistake as some question types in the finals are new to me.
Not enough qualification to grade the TA.

Teach yourself.
reviews.comment_grading:
My friend once told me that if a concrete grading system that lists out score vs corr. sub-grades aren't given at the start of the semester, then it isn't really absolute.

Item (weighting, score):
Homework (0.15, 0.80) I'm a game addict who forgot to do his hw aight?
Mid-term (0.35, 0.9)
Final (0.5, 0.75)

Overall 81%, B+
Meh, fair is fair. Could have done better.
reviews.comment_workload: None if you have M2 background and wishes to get a B.

reviews.author: LizZy
reviews.comment_content:
the course started from SET to the FUNDAMENTAL THEOREM OF CALCULUS, containing Sandwich(Squeeze) Theorem, Linear Approximation, Newton's Method, Intermediate Value Theorem, Mean Value Theorem,  Rolle's Theorem, L'Hopital Rule, Reimann Sum, etc.


they are relatively easy. for many students may have already studied them before.
but it still may contain something you have not learnt in high school
reviews.comment_teaching:
Dr. Chang is willing to answer question. you can ask him during the break(we have a 3-minute break every lecture) or after class. and for mainland students, you will feel comfortable for you can ask your questions in Mandarin.

however,the examples he used is a little too easy(though they are already enough for you to understand the knowledge),so if you want to get extremely good grades, you should either be already very good at math or pay more attention to the tutorial questions.
reviews.comment_grading:
this course is absolute grading.
15% online homework(with unlimited attempts)
35% Mid-term
50% Final
-Total score
85-100%-->A range
70-85%-->B range
50-70%-->C range
40-50%-->D
0-40%-->Fail
since the homework has unlimited attempts, as long as you try to finish it, you will get 15% of the grades. and that is a lot for the exam may be a little more difficult than you think!
(and it seems the mean is not important for this course...)
reviews.comment_workload:
i think this course has very light workload.

for this semester, we totally have 9 online homework, which contain no more than 20 questions.

attendance is not required

for the exams, you should make full use of the sample papers so that you will know the format of the exams, which haven't been changed for years.

reviews.author: Tommy Li
reviews.title: Not good but not bad
reviews.comment_content:
This is an introductory course in one-variable calculus. Topics include functions and graphs, limits of functions and continuity, derivatives and their applications, basic indefinite and definite integrals.

Just a little bit more than M2 syllabus, namely mean value theorem, extreme value theorem, newton's method and l'hospital rule. The content is not difficult for normal M2 students. Practice more on the new topics and you will be fine. :)

Once I managed to prove "n-degree polynomial have at most n roots" using M.I. and the Rolle's theorem (mean value theorem) myself. I really get amazed about the usefulness of MVT and the approximation methods taught in this course.
reviews.comment_teaching:
I would say her teaching is boring (mainly because of her tone and the content) but it is very clear. She did point out explicitly some of the important points in midterm/exam during class. There are some practice time during the lesson  which is quite good for people that bad at math.

I especially like her hand written notes which the logic is clear and easy to follow. The examples are useful too.

I sometime felt asleep in class, but it is easy to pick up the progress. Even reading the notes suffice if you are the kind of person who hates to attend lesson. (I did attend every lesson tho)

The TA, Kenneth Ng, is really good too. He explains the concepts in details and I feel his passion in teaching. But sadly he got resigned after this semester.
reviews.comment_grading:
Absolute grading with no tolerance. Although the mean for the exam is quite low for this semester, the grading still adhere to the standard math grading scheme.

100% ≥ A+/A/A- ≥ 85% > B+/B/B- ≥ 70% > C+/C/C- ≥ 50% > D ≥ 40% > F

HW: 15/15
Midterm: 86/100 (Mean: 66.8)
Exam: 74/100 (Mean: 53.66)
Overall: 82.1/100 B+

Most non-honor version of UST courses are competition for carefulness. The problems are not that hard and it is not that difficult to get an A range. I lost 6 points in exam just because I blacken the wrong answer on the MC answer sheet. Another 9 points because of forgetting to flip the sign or chain rule during differentiation. It would have been an A- if I have been more careful.
reviews.comment_workload: Each week we have to complete 1 exercise of about 10 problems in webwork. Not much workload overall.

I messed up the mid term exam (which is easy). Luckily I did way better on the final exam (which is harder). At the end I got A range.

Here are the mean scores for the lecture session I attend.

reviews.author: grateful grade
reviews.comment_content:
It's mostly dse m2 topics.
Week 1 Review of the concepts of functions and graphs.  (1.1-1.3; Appendix A.)
Week 2 Elementary functions.  (1.4-1.5; Appendix D.)
Week 3 Tangent and velocity; the limit of  a function and limit laws.  (2.1-2.3.)
Week 4 Continuity; limit at infinity; limit definition of derivative and rates of change.  (2.5-2.7.)
Week 5 Derivatives of basic functions; differentiation rules.  (2.8, 3.1-3.3.)
Week 6 Chain rule and implicit differentiation.  (2.8, 3.1-3.3.)
Week 7 Rates and related rates.  (3.7-3.9.)
Week 8 Linear approximation and differentials; Newton's method; Maximum and minimum values.  (3.10, 4.8, 4.1.)
Week 9 Mean Value Theorem; derivatives and the shape of a graph; L'Hopital's Rule.  (4.2-4.4.)
Week 10 Curve sketching; optimization problems.  (4.5-4.7.)
Week 11 Antiderivatives; areas and distance travelled.  (4.9, 5.1.)
Week 12 Definite integrals; Fundamental Theorem of Calculus.  (5.2-5.3.)
Week 13 Net change; substitution rule.  (5.4-5.5.)

People who studied m2 before will have great advantage in this course
reviews.comment_teaching: Tklam is willing to answer our questions after lectures. The teaching is bit boring tho
reviews.comment_grading: It's absolute grading. 15% webwork, 35% midterm , 50% final exam. can get good grades upon enough practices of past papers. Need to note that MC questions worth a lot in the examinations. Need to be very careful when doing multiple choice questions

reviews.author: WaiHei

reviews.comment_grading: The grading is quite harsh that is fixed for a range of F< 40% < D < 50% < C < 70% < B < 85% < A instead of distributed by a curve. But if you have studied hard, you can get a good grade
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is fine. You may need to hand in one homework within two weeks and the difficulty of the homework is not very high.

reviews.comment_teaching: The notes of Prof Ye are really clear. She has a strong Chinese accent but then she speaks quite slowly, so it is easy to understand. However, since the notes are so clear, you can basically skip her lectures and go through the notes by yourself at home. I would say that you shouldn't skip the lectures if you didn't study M2 in DSE.
reviews.comment_grading:

reviews.comment_content: An introduction to Calculus. Here you will learn how to use calculus to solve many different types of problems from previous 19th century maths.

reviews.author: phdoggo
reviews.comment_content: Those introductory calculus topics. It's cumbersome but necessary. Spring content are the same as Fall content, check this somewhere else.
reviews.comment_teaching:
I am totally impressed and motivated by prof. Chiang's teaching. He aware that the class is made up of underperformer in maths. Rather than challenging materials, he introduced math and calculus in a general manner. With detailed steps and proofs in his note, He shows calculus is nothing fancy mathemagic but a humble tool derived from simple axioms to solve problems.

He encourages students to reason calculus on a philosophical level, challenging our fundamental perception of the world. he waved a huge impact on me and make math once interesting again.

This is not any kind of advertisement but a heartfelt gratitude and appreciation to professor Chiang.
reviews.comment_grading: The grading in the spring semester is much less harsh than the summer, due to the general low performance. Mean is less than 50%, hence getting close to 60 %already yields an A.
reviews.comment_workload:
weekly webwork assignment which, if you recall from the fall semester 1013, are made up of the exact identical problems.

weekly tutorials are single page worksheets with demonstration by TA in class. It is though helpful.

reviews.author: chpoonag
reviews.comment_content:
It is basically about calculus. If you studied M2, it should be pretty easy.

Week 1 Review of the concepts of functions and graphs.
Week 2 Elementary functions.
Week 3 Tangent and velocity; the limit of a function and limit laws.
Week 4 Continuity; limit at infinity; limit definition of derivative and rates of change.
Week 5 Derivatives of basic functions; differentiation rules.
Week 6 Chain rule and implicit differentiation.
Week 7 Rates and related rates.
Week 8 Linear approximation and differentials; Newton’s method; Maximum and mini-
mum values.
Week 9 Mean Value Theorem; derivatives and the shape of a graph; L’Hopital’s Rule.
Week 10 Curve sketching; optimization problems.
Week 11 Antiderivatives; areas and distance travelled.
Week 12 Definite integrals; Fundamental Theorem of Calculus.
Week 13 Net change; substitution rule.
reviews.comment_teaching: It may be boring for the lecture as theories and proofs were explained in class. Only few time was about doing questions. However, I would say that Prof Hu is quite modest. You can point out anything he may have done wrongly during class directly. Additionally, he is quite patient in answering students' questions after class. He can spend half an hour answering our questions in another room after the lecture. Every time, there were about 5 people asking him, ranging from the local and the mainland students.
reviews.comment_grading:
Absolute grading.

15% homework (WeBWork)
35% midterm
50% final

There are both MC and long questions in the midterm and final exam papers, unlike those papers of this course in earlier years.

Be careful in MC questions in midterm. Each account for 5 marks.

There are unlimited attempts in WeBWork without any mark deduction.
reviews.comment_workload: Not high. The WeBWork is easy for those who have grasped the basic knowledge in secondary schools already. For M1 students, you may have to pay more effort as the topics are not entirely covered in college.

but a tip is to keep attending the tutorial session since it help to keep track of the course and get the idea of what is taught in the lecture
reviews.comment_grading:
Final grade: B+
Midterm 35% (72/100, mean:68)
Final 50% (81/100, Mean:66.35)
Webwork 15% (full marks)
reviews.comment_workload: Mainly from Webwork

reviews.author: occheung
reviews.comment_content:
This course covers the fundamental aspect of calculus.
Topics:
Functions, limit and derivatives, differentiation rules, differentiation applications, basic integrations.
some featured topics: Inverse functions, continuity and differentiability, linear approximation, mean value theorem, optimization.
reviews.comment_teaching:
This lecturer has very heavy mainland accent. So some pronunciation are quite off the standard.

However, he can improve your math concept quite well, especially on connecting different topics conceptually. His teaching pace is quite fast and will leave the last lecture before mid-term/final as review section (try out exam paper)
He also provides extra past paper through canvas, which is great for practicing and getting a grasp of the difficulty of the exam.
reviews.comment_grading:
Homework: 15%
Mid-term: 35%
Final: 50%

Mid-term and exams are both quite easy.
Getting all MC questions right makes your chance of getting a strong grade much higher. In most case, MC questions accounts for half of the score of a test or exam. It is very important to be careful on those.

Long questions can be very clumsy, but still easy.

My score:
Midterm: 97/100
Final: 94/100
Total score: 95.95/100
I got A+ for this course.
reviews.comment_workload:
Workload is not high if you have good mathematics foundations or even good knowledge of calculus.
Honestly, it is just high school calculus and slightly bit harder.
However, practices does help for quite a bit.
The only workload is homework, mid-term and exam.

reviews.author: Nicole MA
reviews.comment_content: The content is very easy during the add-drop period, and then it gets harder. Because there is no ppt before the class, you have to attend the lectures and take notes. There is no assignment and project, no attendance is required, and overall the content is not very difficult.
reviews.comment_teaching: TK is patient and always makes things quite clear for everyone to understand. However, that makes him sometimes too slow to draw attention. He never uses ppt, so he writes in class and uses the projector. His writing is not always clear, which may be hard to recognize if you do not attend the lectures or pay full attention to what he says.
reviews.comment_grading: The grading is not by curve, so get a good mark, and a good grade is granted. There are plenty of past papers and make sure you practice with them before the exams, because they help a lot, and sometimes the questions are similar.
reviews.comment_workload: Being a fundamental course, MATH1013 is easy enough to understand and perform well with medium attention and work. However, you do need to complete all the 10 homework online, which can be torturous as you type in answers over and over again, for a long period of time.

reviews.comment_content: Basic calculus include differentiation, integration and others like function and inverse function. If you have taken M2 in DSE then there are not many new contents to you.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Wang has some weird accent, but understandable. In lecture, he always prove the equations before introducing new chapters to us. Sometimes it is difficult to follow because he may use some techniques that are not include in the course scope. Before mid-term, he will go through pastpaper with us and that helped me a lot in my mid-term exam.
Leung Ho Ming is a great TA, his teaching style is exam-oriented, which fits me perfectly as i have already learn most of the cotent in high school M2. In his notes, he use many different example question to explain the techniques we can apply in different cases. There are also practice questions in his notes, you can have a try but they are pretty challenging.
reviews.comment_grading: It is a required course for most of the students so the grading won’t be that good as many have taken M2 in DSE. i scored 1.5 sd above mean in mid-term, about 0.5 sd above mean in final, got an A-.
reviews.comment_workload: WebWork per 1-2weeks, honestly speaking it is not that heavy, if you really dont know how to do, google is your best friend. But I encourage not to google every question because Wework is the only way you can test out how familiar you are with the content you have learnt. Also, you can attempt the question many times as there are no penalty for wrong answers. Try until you really dont have an idea.

reviews.comment_content:
